Name: Aguas Arriba
Description: A lakeside lodge deep in the heart of Patagonia with views of mount Fitz Roy, overlooking a hanging glacier and only accessible by boat, or a day hike. Aguas Arriba is a wonderful base for off the beaten track hiking, fishing or simply relaxing. The hosts are friendly and with just six rooms it has a cosy atmosphere. Our number one recommendation in the El Chaltén/Fitz Roy area.
What we like about this hotel:
• The lodge is the only place to stay on this enchanting lake. Accessible by boat or a three-hour hike, there is hardly a soul on the surrounding trails.
  • Remote with an edge-of-the-earth feeling... yet accessible. 
  • Its all-inclusive programme includes boat trips and hikes up to hanging glaciers with friendly, knowledgeable guides.
  • The food is superb - prepare for both quality and quantity!
  • With as many staff as guests, you are looked after every step of the way and feel completely at home.
  • 3 nights here pairs well with 2 or 3 days in the trekker paradise of El Chaltén plus time in El Calafate and a visit to Perito Moreno Glacier.
We think its worth noting:
• This is a very secluded location and not everyone is comfortable being as off-grid as this. 
  • It doesn't replace the famous hikes from El Chaltén but is a lovely (more relaxing) addition to them.
What they say about this accommodation: This has to be one of the most relaxing places I've ever stayed. The setting is sensational, it's as if you have the lake entirely to yourself. You are so well looked after by the staff who are incredibly friendly while providing a first-class service. Having no WiFi and phone signal is total bliss...

Name: Albatros
Description: The original 4-star hotel in Ushuaia, now slightly dated, the Albatros has the most central location in town, directly in front of the main Ushuaia Port making it convenient for embarking on cruises or exploring the waterfront area. Standard rooms have a stylish feel with wooden or modern furniture, small but comfortable. A decent buffet breakfast is served daily and the restaurant offers a wide variety of international dishes.

Name: Alma del Lago
Description: This hotel offers high-end quality while being based in the centre of town. There's a lovely indoor pool with large glass windows that offer views of the lake. It is one of the three hotels in Bariloche that offers room service. Guests can choose between dining at an upscale restaurant or enjoying more affordable meals at a bistro. The hotel's modern architecture includes plenty of glass, following local regulations that require lakefront properties to maintain visual appeal for the public.

Name: Altiplánico
Description: This upmarket four-storey hotel in the centre of the city is an excellent choice. It's right in the heart of the main tourist attractions so there's no need to use the metro. The hotel has 24 rooms, including six suites, spread over four floors. All rooms are very well appointed in a modern and uncluttered style. There are also two delightful interior patios where you can enjoy a relaxing drink, away from the bustle of the city. All the services you would expect of an upmarket hotel are on offer, including a 24hr reception and an honesty bar.

Name: Altiplánico Atacama
Description: On the edge of town (a 10-min gentle stroll from the centre), the family-owned Altiplanico provides a sense of comfort in what is otherwise a rather rough landscape. The interior is filled with calm, birdsong and a spacious, beautifully manicured desert garden. All rooms have a terrace and feature outdoor showers - excellent for star-gazing! The hotel doesn't arrange tours and although you book on a B&B basis, there is a simple lunch and evening menu.

Name: Alto Andino
Description: This is a modern hotel just two blocks from San Martin, the main street in Ushuaia. The breakfast room is up on the top floor and has clear views out across the water; as do some of the bedrooms on the higher floors. There are also a couple of apartments if you prefer the independence of cooking for yourself from time to time. Staff are very friendly and the hotel is light, airy and spacious.

Name: Amonite
Description: This hotel is well located in the heart of the heart of San Martín, just two blocks from the lake's beach and entrance of the town. It's a family-run Apart-hotel that feels like a small ski lodge and is great for semi-independent travellers and families looking to cook some basic meals. There's an indoor and outdoor pool, a small sauna, plus an outdoor quincho for sitting around and taking your own meals. Each room has a kitchenette with basic to complex kitchen amenities. The hotel does not have dining options, and a basic breakfast is delivered to your room each morning. The friendly staff speak some English and are very helpful. The hotel has a lift.

Name: Arakur
Description: The resort is nestled in the mountains above Ushuaia and offers extraordinary views over the Beagle Channel (particularly from the spa). They have a private nature reserve offering at least half a day of wonderful hiking and exploration either with or without a guide. You’ll be 20 minutes from town by shuttle bus or taxi. Comfortable beds, friendly English-speaking staff and striking architecture stand out features here. And if you want to get a feel for the wilderness of Tierra del Fuego rather than the urban life of Ushuaia and have the budget, then this is the best option.

Name: Awasi Atacama
Description: Awasi offer 'tailor-made' journeys, rather than 'all-inclusive' programs. They offer a 4x4 vehicle and personal guide for each room who will meet you at the airport and help you to plan the whole of your stay at Awasi. The walled environment creates an intimate oasis of calm with fire pits, sun shades and plenty of trees. The restaurant here is particularly well-regarded.
What they say about this accommodation: Nothing is too much to ask for. When I stayed there, a musician asked at 10pm for Awasi to find him a guitar to entertain his friends. Instead of saying, ‘No, that isn’t possible at this time of evening’, they asked him if he preferred an electric or acoustic one.

Name: Awasi
Description: Awasi takes seclusion to another level. Set in its own private reserve just outside the national park, it offers breathtaking views of the Paine Massif, Lake Sarmiento and the pampa. There are 14 villa cabins, surrounded trees for privacy. Their design is taken from traditional Patagonian shelters, with a modern luxury finish. Each has its own private terrace and hot tub. All guests have their own guide and 4x4 vehicle for exploring at their own pace. After a day's adventure, guests can relax with a gourmet meal at Awasi’s Relais & Chåteaux restaurant, inspired by seasonal native flavours from the lodge’s kitchen garden. Awasi Patagonia: Essential information: Located in a private reserve near the eastern edge of Torres del Paine National Park - Individual secluded cabins offer an air of real exclusivity - Each cabin comes with its own private guide and vehicle, allowing guests to create their own itinerary - A Relais & Châteaux property, with a restaurant serving superb cuisine and wine
What we like about this hotel:
• You have your own private guide and 4x4 vehicle, so you can explore at your own pace, following off-the-beaten-track hiking trails.
  • The native fauna remains intact, and herds of guanacos, ñandus, foxes, condors and pumas can be spotted.
  • Soak in your hot tub, have a drink by the fire and enjoy long evening meals in the Relais & Chateaux restaurant.
  • The stunning, secluded setting gives the hotel an exclusive feel, with more than enough space to roam or relax.
  • Each villa is individually designed with a stunning view across to the iconic towers, Lake Sarmiento or the Patagonian steppe.
We think its worth noting:
• All the villas have privacy and are in their own space which we love, but means you need to walk a fair distance or get a lift if you don't want to be exposed to the elements on your way to dinner. 
  • It is a 40-minute drive from Awasi to the edge of the National Park and if you take the Grey Glacier excursion then you will be travel for 3 hours. There are better-located lodges for those keen to hike the W Trek.
What they say about this accommodation: The thing that appeals most about Awasi Patagonia is the freedom to explore Torres del Paine with your own guide and vehicle.

Name: B&B Cerro Castillo
Description: This B&B nestled in Villa Cerro Castillo, on the edge of the eponymous national park, offers an authentic slice of rural Patagonia. You'll stay in a cosy room with stunning views of Cerro Castillo and the Río Ibáñez. The refugio is well-equipped for adventurers, providing a convenient base for exploring the region's trekking, horseback riding, and climbing opportunities. Additional comforts include breakfast, Wi-Fi, and private parking, enhancing your stay in this picturesque area.

Name: Bader Climber's Camp
Description: Bader Climber's Camp is a remote campsite with no facilities and only a limited number of pitches. It can only be used when booked in advance with CONAF (the national park authority) and when hiking with a guide.

Name: Bahía Bustamante
Description: A wildlife haven well worth the four hour drive from Puerto Madryn. Escape to the wilderness, with no phone reception and only generator powered electricity. Explore petrified forests, endless beaches, and diverse marine life on foot, by horse and by boat.
What they say about this accommodation: Not even the roaring winds that swept along the coast during my stay at Bahia Bustamante could take away from how special this place is. In fact, it only added to the feeling of remoteness and the authenticity. You can really disconnect from everything here - physically and mentally - and that is rare these days!

Name: Barraco Lodge
Description: A unique and secluded refuge set in 150 acres of pristine rainforest overlooking glistening turquoise lakes and dramatic valleys. Ideally located for exploring the wild rivers, hidden waterfalls, forests and mountains of the Tagua Tagua National Park
What they say about this accommodation: Barracco lodge epitomises rustic luxury in a stunning and remote Southern corner of the Lake District. Their ethos is to make guests feel like they are visiting a hospitable friend's house where the hospitality is informal and limitless. For the adventurous, days can be filled with hiking, paddle boarding, horseback riding, fly-fishing and mountain biking. Barraco Lodge is a hidden gem!

Name: BordeBaker Lodge
Description: Seven exquisitely designed cabins perched atop the banks of the Baker River make up BordeBaker Lodge, surrounded by southern beech forest and connected by wooden walkways. The striking architecture of the self-contained wooden cabins perfectly compliments the natural setting. Listen to the rush of the river and the whip of the wind while relaxing in your spacious bedroom with a woodburner. Enjoy total privacy or get to know other guests in the communal 'Casona' with floor-to-ceiling windows and spectacular mountain views, unwinding after a day's hiking, rafting, kayaking, fishing or boat tripping.

Name: Cabo de Hornos
Description: A centrally-located hotel, right on the main square, with views of the Magellan Strait. It's a five-minute walk from the bus station, port, and main high street for restaurants. Cabo de Hornos has a polished, business-like feel to it and is a perfect base for those looking for something classic and comfortable. The food is not outstanding, but there are lots of other options on your doorstep.

Name: Cacique Inacayal Lake & Spa Hotel
Description: You’re located right on the lakefront, with the ground-floor rooms given direct access to the grassy lawn and stony beachfront, where both hotel guests and the local birdlife congregate. Rooms are equipped with designer furniture, WiFi, minibar, TV, digital safe and a modern bathroom. There is a good pool and extensive breakfast. Downtown is just 10 minutes walk away.

Name: Caleta Gonzalo Lodge
Description: Caleta Gonzalo Lodge is home to a series of simple but very cosy wooden cabins with balconies tucked into the forest and looking out over the fjords, allowing you to wake to the sound of birdsong and watch dolphins from your bed. Home-cooked food is served in the restaurant, with vegetables grown in the lodge’s garden. The lodge backs straight onto the Cascadas Trail, making it a perfect place for hikers.

Name: Campamento Torres
Description: Campmento Torres is one of three campsites in Torres del Paine maintained by CONAF, the national park authority. It's not in proximity to any refugios, so you have nature all to yourself. When operating, the campsite must be booked in advance. Only simple facilities are on offer: wood platforms for pitching tents, cooking shelter and a long-drop toilet. There are no showers.

Name: Carpa Manzano
Description: Clean and comfortable, the Carpa Manzano offers few surprises, as would be expected at this price point. Guests, however, repeatedly note the particularly helpful staff that work here. It is a little out of town – fifteen minutes from the main square and a fifteen-minute drive from the airport. The dining area is lovely and open, with views over the town. Although the rooms are basic, they have everything you need.

Name: Casa Kalfu
Description: Casa Kalfu celebrates and embodies the local architectural tradition. The hotel is well located in a quiet area, about 10mins walk from the town. There's a comfortable lounge and 14 guest rooms, though there no views of the lake or volcano. This place is best suited to families rather than groups of friends. Kalfu means blue in the language of the Mapuche people who have inhabited the region for centuries.

Name: Casa Solaria
Description: Hotel Casa Solaria features accommodation with a terrace, free private parking and a bar. This 4-star hotel offers room service, a 24-hour front desk and free WiFi. The property is non-smoking and is located 22km from Ojos del Caburgua Waterfall while Villarrica National Park is 10 km from the property. At the hotel, all rooms include a wardrobe. Complete with a private bathroom fitted with a shower and free toiletries, the rooms have a flat-screen TV and air conditioning, and certain rooms are fitted with a balcony. At the accommodation rooms have bed linen and towels.

Name: Casa Sur Recoleta
Description: The sister property of the Casa Sur in Palermo, this is our top boutique hotel in Recoleta, situated right in the centre of the district. It is artistic, characterful, and close to the buzzing restaurants and parks of Recoleta.

Name: Castillo Rojo
Description: As the name suggests, this castle looking building, looks like something out of a fairytale with turrets and balconies. Recently restored and open for just one year, the interior of this building restains all of its original charm original features, antiques and furniture made and sourced in Chile. The rooms vary in size, but all offer character and comfort.

Name: Chaltén Camp
Description: Set in a secluded location, several kilometres from town, this camp accommodates 18 guests. Accommodation is is cosy, modern, eco-friendly geodesic domes with stunning views of Mt Fitz Roy. You’ll feel that you’re sleeping in the wild, but with all the comfort of a hotel room. Meals are served in the large main dome which is also a great place in which to relax and meet other travellers.
What we like about this hotel:
• The camp is in a secluded location - only 18 guests can stay here at a time so you'll be well away from the crowds.
  • Stay in a cosy, modern, eco-friendly, geodesic dome.
  • You’ll feel that you are sleeping in the wild, but with all the comfort of a hotel room.
  • There is no other accommodation like it in El Chaltén
  • Savour views of the magnificent Fitz Roy which presents stunning dawn photo opportunities.
  • The food is tasty, nourishing and freshly prepared each day.
We think its worth noting:
• If you don’t have transport it can be expensive to get a taxi into town. You also have to book a day in advance as there are not many. 
  • Domes can get cold when the log burner is not going (you need to know how to maintain it).
  • They can also get battered by the wind which can be noisy during the night.
What they say about this accommodation: With the creek nearby, and the solitude, you can sit and watch sunset and sunrise at your leisure and listen to the trickle of water and tiny chirping birds. I also LOVED the hot water bottles provided for those fresh Patagonian mornings.

Name: Chaltén Suites
Description: The Chaltén Suites is situated on the main street in town and has everything you'd need close by. It has a higher standard and level of comfort than most in town, with spacious rooms and friendly staff. A perfect base if you are staying in El Chaltén for more than a couple of days.

Name: Cilene del Faro
Description: Made up of 48 spacious and modern apartments, this option is great for those who want a bit more space. The apartments have kitchenettes giving you freedom to cook when and what you want. The location is good again - a few metres from the Beagle Channel and Ushuaia's museums. You can enjoy a drink from the bar at the top of the hotel with panoramic views. Guests also have access to an exclusive spa and swimming pool giving the chance to unwind.

Name: Cilene del Fuego Suites & Spa
Description: Smart, clean, apartment-style accommodation with wonderful views of the Beagle Channel and the mountains. Their suites provide more space and amenities than a traditional hotel room. The hotel boasts a central location just off the main street, Avenida San Martín. This puts you within easy walking distance of shops, restaurants, and the marina. The spa has a big indoor heated pool, sauna (for 2 or 3 people), and small gym. Very nice after an active day in Tierra del Fuego!

Name: Continental 725
Description: If your stopover is brief in the city then this hotel is a good choice. Located right in the centre with stunning views from its rooftop pool bar, it's a two minute walk from the main historic sights and right in the thick of the hustle and bustle that drives this city.

Name: Correntoso Hotel
Description: With one of the best pools in the region and a super lakeside location, Correntoso is one to check out. Most of the rooms have large windows offering great views of the lake and there are lots of areas to relax around the hotel. They also have a private boat and do live music at the lakeside restaurant once a week.

Name: Coyhaique River Lodge
Description: This charming retreat blends comfort with adventure in Patagonia's pristine wilderness. Double and single rooms both have a luxurious yet homey feel, set against the scenic river valley surroundings. You can unwind in the common areas or treat yourself with onsite restaurant dining, a hot tub, and available massages. The lodge also boasts an inviting lounge with a fireplace, perfect for relaxing after a day's adventure. From December to March, they offer all-inclusive, week-long stays that let you truly disconnect and explore beautiful Aysen.

Name: Dazzler
Description: Clean and comfortable, with excellent views of the Golfo Nuevo, the Dazzler is well situated in the heart of town, right on the sea front. It has free wifi as well as a fitness centre and spa. The best rooms are on the higher floors, with balconies to allow you to fully appreciate those sunsets over the bay.

Name: Dazzler Palermo
Description: Large, functional and well located, this hotel offers a great low cost offer in Palermo whilst still offering clean, spacious and private rooms. There is an outdoor pool and a large, bright dining area where breakfast is served. As with any large hotel, it offers the usual services which aren't always available in the smaller boutique hotels. This hotel is great for those on a limited budget still looking to get under the skin of trendy Palermo.

Name: Del Nómade
Description: This eco-lodge won first prize in the inaugural 'Green Hotels of Argentina' contest and is just a five minute walk from Pirámides Beach. It's set amongst lovely gardens and is close to all of the restaurants. There are eight double rooms, all with private bathrooms, and the ground-floor rooms have private terraces. The buffet breakfasts are wonderful, including plenty of homemade produce, and the staff are extremely friendly and helpful.

Name: Desertica
Description: This 12-room three-star boutique hotel is located right in the centre of town. It's built around an orchard which provides plenty of quiet spaces to sit. There's a stylish mid-sized pool, but it's on view to those coming and going from reception. Solar energy powers the hotel; WiFi is available and there are no televisions.

Name: Destino Sur
Description: A very clean and comfortable hotel with modern, alpine-styled rooms, it's a big hit with travellers looking for a lovely place to come home to each night with a good breakfast for the morning. You are less than a kilometre from Los Glaciares National Park and the hotel has a small indoor pool/spa, a sauna and mountain views from most of the rooms. Customers also recognise the hard work of the staff at Destino Sur each year.

Name: Don Tomas
Description: This is another option on the edge of town, but that's not much of a problem given the size of San Pedro - it's only a 15-minute stroll to the centre. The friendly staff have varying proficiency in English but are always smiling and doing their best to help. Overall Don Tomas is a good, mid-range hotel with soft, large beds in clean, spacious rooms.

Name: Dreams Coyhaique
Description: Like a modern beacon amongst the traditional wooden houses, Dreams hotel is Coyhaique's biggest hotel and towers above its surroundings. With great height comes stunning views, you can eat your breakfast looking out across the city, all the way to the tree-clad hills in the distance. The staff have easy smiles, are incredibly helpful and speak good English. The rooms are typical of an upmarket hotel, with a swirling patterns on the carpet and a wooden finish to furniture. There is a casino, sky bar and buffet restaurant on site, and it's located just a short walk from the main square.

Name: Duhau Palace - Park Hyatt
Description: Park Hyatt is a luxury hotel located in the traditional Recoleta neighbourhood. The two-building complex combines the elegance of an aristocratic palace with sophisticated contemporary design. Enjoy the experience of a residential stay in spacious rooms and suites; explore Argentine haute cuisine from talented chefs; see a curated private art collection; Relax in (possibly) the best spa in Buenos Aires and delight in memorable experiences in its inspiring gardens.

Name: EcoCamp
Description: EcoCamp is situated in the heart of Torres del Paine National Park in a beautiful site with stunning sunset views out to the iconic Towers. The campsite consists of a series of cosy geodesic domes linked together by wooden walkways, as well as a larger dome that serves as a restaurant and bar, and offers a relaxed, sociable atmosphere after a day's hiking in the park. Each dome includes a private terrace, en-suite bathroom and a wood stove that is lit for guests every evening. EcoCamp is run along strict low-impact environmental guidelines, with solar power, biofilter water systems, composting facilities and its own vegetable garden. EcoCamp: Essential information: Within walking distance of the trailhead of the Base of the Towers trek - Option to take a multi-day hike on the W or Full Circuit trail with some of the nights at the camp and others in refugios - Multiple excursions offered every day, including a puma tracking programme for wildlife enthusiasts - Dedicated yoga dome and massage treatments available - Friendly communal atmosphere, where you have dinner with your group from the day's excursion
What we like about this hotel:
• The camp’s sustainability and eco-friendly ethos mean minimum impact on the park
  • Located right by the trailhead, you can walk to the towers from your dome
  • EcoCamp has amazing views across to the iconic Paine Massif, particularly stunning at sunrise and sunset
  • The Community Domes, with terraces for lounging and enjoying the view, a chillout area, twice daily yoga sessions and a welcoming bar, give a relaxed and communal feel 
  • Fall asleep gazing at the stars through your dome skylight
We think its worth noting:
• There is no WIFI at EcoCamp and whilst we love a digital detox, it isn't for everyone
  • Composting toilets are an important part of EcoCamp's sustainability commitment but they do come with a natural odour. 
  • The Standard domes have a shared toilet and when the camp is full you may need to queue. It can also be cold and may require a wet dash from the dome to the toilet block at night
  • Meals at the EcoCamp are eaten at long tables and introverts may not love this group dynamic. It is great for solo travellers though.
What they say about this accommodation: The guides at EcoCamp think of themselves as hosts welcoming you into their home, and the entire place brims with conviviality and warmth - it has the spirit of a backpackers’ hostel, but with much better beds!

Name: El Casco
Description: On the shores of Nahuel Huapi Lake, this hotel provides luxurious accommodation in a building designed to complement its surroundings. El Casco is an 'art hotel' with a large collection of Argentinian artwork, with each of its suites named after an artist and containing some of his work. The hotel's location makes it well-suited for those looking for an adventure in the Argentinian lake district, without sacrificing any comfort.

Name: El Galpon del Glaciar
Description: About a half hours’ drive from El Calafate on the shores of Lago Argentina, El Galpon del Glaciar is an estancia that has been converted into a rustic boutique guesthouse. The ranch still raises sheep and has sheepdog demonstrations and shearing, plus evening tango in the restaurant. To connect with nature, you can saddle up your horse here, with full or half day excursions for riders of all levels of experience. The diverse landscape here means that you can ride on the beach and dunes as well as the pampa. The lakeside location gives access to the nearby Reserva Natural Laguna de los Pájaros, where there are hides for observing many species of water bird, including flocks of flamingos.

Name: El Mirador de Guadal
Description: Perched on the shores of Lago General Carrera with views of its turquoise waters, snow-capped mountains and the Northern Patagonian Ice Field, El Mirador de Guadal is a lodge that will make you never want to leave. Bright, spacious wooden cabins with huge windows, natural, simple decor, wood burners and terraces overlooking the lake are dotted along the lakeside, all with access to the beach. The lodge offers excursions to the Marble Caves, the Exploradores Valley near Laguna San Rafael National Park, the Baker River and Patagonia National Park.

Name: El Paso
Description: El Paso is one of three campsites in Torres del Paine maintained by CONAF, the national park authority. It's not in proximity to any refugios, so you have nature all to yourself. When operating, the campsite must be booked in advance. Only simple facilities are on offer: wood platforms for pitching tents, cooking shelter and a long-drop toilet. There are no showers.

Name: El Reloj
Description: Reloj' means clock, and the hotel is so named after the cuckoo clock which hangs on the wall and chimes every hour. Opened in 2001, it is one of Coyhaique's older hotels. The owner Angel is warm and welcoming, passionate about the building which he transformed from being a saw mill into a comfortable hotel. There is a comfy sitting room reception, a restaurant decorated with plush old world furniture, a sun room to enjoy both sunny and rainy days, and even a small garden filled with fruit trees from which they make jams for breakfast. Despite being just off one of Coyhaique's main streets, El Relj backs onto the Coyhaique river with views across the reserve, and looking out across the gorge you really feel like you're out of town.

Name: Emperador Hotel
Description: Indulge in luxury at a hotel where custom-made beds and Italian marble bathrooms await. Located in the elegant Recoleta district, this haven offers a spa, gym, and an indoor pool, all just steps from vibrant dining and cultural attractions. Unwind in refined comfort at the Emperador Hotel for an unforgettable Buenos Aires experience.

Name: Entre Hielos Lodge
Description: Entre Hielos Lodge is the best place to stay in Caleta Tortel. Make your way up the wooden stairway that climbs through the trees to spacious lodge, then look out from your bedroom window  across native temperate rainforest and breathe in the clean air. Rooms are warm and relaxing with walls made from Guaitecas Cypress wood. All have comfortable beds with thick down duvets, en suite bathrooms and central heating. You can do a number of excursions from the lodge, including boat rides down the Baker River and visits to nearby glaciers. Dine at the lodge's own restaurant, which provides classic Patagonian dishes made with local ingredients.

Name: EOLO
Description: If you're looking for a place of luxury and hosts who will pamper you and provide private guides for excursions, hotel EOLO is the place for you. Go horse riding (for a small additional cost), trekking and mountain biking, or wildlife spotting amid the great vistas of La Anita Valley and Mount Frias, knowing that a tasteful and comfortable home is awaiting you at the end of your day.
What we like about this hotel:
• Only a 20-minute drive from El Calafate, Eolo feels just remote enough without requiring long travel times to get there.
  • The sense of isolation and peace that brings. 
  • Sip a glass of Malbec while watching the changing light on the landscape through the floor-to-ceiling windows.
  • The service is faultless, with attentive, welcoming staff.
  • Eolo is a Relais & Chateaux hotel, and the fresh, beautifully presented food does not disappoint.
  • Go horseriding, trekking, mountain biking or wildlife spotting amid the great vistas of La Anita Valley and Mount Frias.
We think its worth noting:
• There are not many included activities on the all-inclusive program so extra costs will be incurred.
  • Eolo does book out in advance so plan ahead.
What they say about this accommodation: What a place. It's great for itineraries in Los Glaciares and probably the most tranquil hotel I've ever visited.  The General Manager, Valentin has been there for 16 years and is an incredible host. It also has my second favourite view from any hotel (after Explora Torres Del Paine!)

Name: Errante EcoLodge
Description: As a base to explore Navarino Island, Errante Ecolodge is a unique and inspiring choice. Their excursions include treks to the island’s best lookouts, kayaking the Beagle Channel, bird watching, and cultural visits to Puerto Williams and the nearby ethno-botanical park. For those seeking deeper adventure, it’s an ideal place to base yourself before and after the Dientes de Navarino trek. You’ll also find thoughtful architecture, a strong sustainability focus, and a creative, community-driven atmosphere that sets it apart.
What we like about this hotel:
• The whole place is beautifully (and sensitively) integrated into the natural surroundings.
  • You'll have incredible views over the Beagle Channel. 
  • The entire lodge is 100% solar powered, with hydropower capacity currently being constructed.
  • Fantastic and tasty, locally-sourced food, based mostly on organic seafood and salmon is some of the best you'll try in Patagonia
  • There are some superb and diverse excursions with the guarantee of returning to the comfort and peace of the lodge every evening.
  • Advanced trekking options can be arranged—with camping overnight—for the ultimate outdoor experience at the end of the world.
We think its worth noting:
• You could almost categorise it as a 'luxury refugio' , blending incredible cuisine with an unstructured and relaxed hostel vibe feel to the place. Visitors will need to go-with-the-flow.
  • The service is not polished but is friendly and down-to-earth, suiting those who enjoy a more casual style.
  • The closest restaurant and shop outside of the lodge is in Puerto Williams, 6km away. 
  • The owner Jorge lives on site, and one of the bedrooms is still dedicated to his dental practice - a quirky aspect of this lodge. 
  • There are no TVs in any of the rooms or communal spaces.
What they say about this accommodation: Getting to the southernmost settlement in the world - Puerto Toro - on Errante's ‘public boat’ service around the island is one of the best things I've done in decades of travel experiences in Patagonia. The virtuous community work done by Jorge, Constanza and their team simply blew me away.

Name: Estancia Cerro Guido
Description: Cerro Guido is the biggest working estancia in the Torres del Paine region, covering 250,000 acres (101,000 hectares) of land. Over a century old, it offers the peace and comfort of a good hotel, but with all the rich character of a traditional Patagonian ranch. The estancia sits in a beautiful location on the eastern border of the national park, where you can enjoy horse-riding, visits with a pioneering conservation programme helping pumas and livestock share the land, or even see where palaeontologists are digging up ancient fossils. Alternatively, just sit back and enjoy a traditional barbecue under an endless sky.
What we like about this hotel:
• At over 100 years old, it takes you back in time as you imagine how gaucho life was in this remote part of the world before Torres del Paine was on the traveller's map.
  • You get the chance to have a more authentic experience by staying in houses that were formerly those of the estancia workers and witnessing gaucho skills such as sheep shearing and horseback riding.
  • It's an extremely comfortable place to stay while visiting Torres del Paine and the surrounding areas, with easy access to the eastern side of the park.
  • The food is superb with three-course meals using organic produce from the estancia's allotments, delicious lamb cooked in the traditional style 'al palo', and some of the finest of Chile's wines being served.
  • Pick from a wide range of excursions that allow you to explore the lesser-visited places surrounding  Torres del Paine National Park like the Baguales mountain range on the Argentinian border and also use it as a base for the most iconic places in the park.
We think its worth noting:
• Cerro Guido is not the best fit for anyone who doesn't want to be so remote or only wants to do the highlight hikes of the W Trek.
  • You have to travel along a lot on a bumpy gravel road to and from the estancia.
What they say about this accommodation: I love this place - it's up there with all the high-end luxury lodges but offers so much more variety. It has something for everyone and much better suited for families of all ages. There's a focus on conservation and the history of the estancia is absorbing. They even have projects that are working with both the estancia and puma/condor conservation - akin to those used on the wildlife conservancies in Kenya.

Name: Estancia Cristina
Description: Estancia Cristina is one of the oldest estancias in Los Glaciares, and is still owned and run by the same family who first established it in 1914, naming it for their daughter. The estancia is gloriously remote: you have to take a private boat from near El Calafate across Lago Argentina to get here, stopping off along the way to look at icebergs and glaciers, then transferring by 4x4 for another hour to reach your destination. The original estancia buildings have been modernised to provide rustic but high end accommodation in the middle of nowhere. The old sheep shearing shed has been converted into a museum. Activities on offer include go horse-riding among the thousands of hectares that surround the estancia, or hike to a variety of scenic locations including the vast and beautiful Upsala Glacier.
What we like about this hotel:
• The chance to explore a lost land of glaciers, mountains, lakes, rivers, refuges, trails, canyons, valleys, and forests. 
  • The mighty Upsala Glacier is located nearby. 
  • Top-level, varied and healthy cuisine with excellent service.
  • This estancia is run with the same effort and perseverance as its founding family from 1914.
  • The museum on-site offers a great chance to learn about the history of the estancia.
We think its worth noting:
• There is not the range of excursions you can expect at other high-end hotels and there is a take-it-or-leave-it approach.
  • There is no electricity from midnight to 6am.
What they say about this accommodation: The boat that Cristina and her family built taking 10 years is now beached on the shore of the lake by the Estancia. We took a walk down to the shore at sunset to shoot some photos of the historical boat which is a big part of the history of the estancia. Seeing the boat weathered and falling apart with the ice-capped mountains reminded me why I love Patagonia so much!

Name: Estancia El Condor
Description: Estancia El Condor has managed to retain a strong sense of its working past. Its deeply remote location gives it a true wilderness homestay atmosphere. Stay here and you’ll feel like Patagonia has emptied to offer you your own private adventure playground. North of El Chaltén, Estancia El Condor sits on a beautiful turquoise stretch of Lago San Martín, surrounded by mountains. The big attraction here is the chance to truly switch off in a remote and spectacular location. Horse riding is available as well as self-guided hikes: this is a landscape that you’ll have completely to yourself that’s begging to be explored. The atmosphere is cosy and authentically rustic with great homemade farm food, but if it's views you're after, few places do it better.
What we like about this hotel:
• This is the most authentic estancia experience in Patagonia (and we've been to all of them!) 
  • Immerse yourself in the low-key, simple lifestyle of the gauchos.
  • The location is just incredible and ideal to escape the crowds, you won’t meet any travellers.
  • Stunning views - The mountains tower above the estancia, while the incredible turquoise San Martin Lake stretches out towards the horizon. 
  • Fantastic riding that experienced riders will love. Many estancias only cater to inexperienced riders. 
  • Good hiking options are also available. 
  • Authentic, home-cooked food sets you up for a day of exploring.
  • With a strong focus on history and conservation, there are lots of opportunities to learn more about this fascinating region.
We think its worth noting:
• It's a 5-hour drive from El Calafate, about 160 km paved road and 120 km gravel road and no phone signal.
  • We don't recommend driving there yourself so you will need a private transfer. 
  • The cost is relatively high for such a rustic experience with simple rooms and simple food.
  • It's truly remote, with nothing around for miles, but the location is hard to beat...
What they say about this accommodation: This is what I imagine when I think of a true Patagonian estancia: a remote building set in stunning scenery and offering some of the best horse riding I’ve done in my life

Name: Estancia Helsingfors
Description: Estancia Helsingfors enjoys some of the best scenery offered by any estancia: the building perches on the edge of Lago Viedma with views of FitzRoy, glaciers and snow-capped peaks right on your doorstep. This estancia has more of a hotel feel, with the focus on comfort and sightseeing rather than more active excursions. If you're after a beautiful setting to relax with a glass of wine and exquisite food, or a relaxed comfortable atmosphere to enjoy the silence and seclusion of Patagonia, this is the estancia for you. Estancia Helsingfors is also the springboard for our Los Glaciares Wilderness Trek. From here, it’s a challenging six days to Estancia Cristina on some of the wildest and most rewarding hiking trails in Los Glaciares.

Name: Estancia Josefina
Description: Looking to get truly off grid? Estancia Josefina offers one of the most remote and exclusive experiences you can have anywhere in Patagonia. Estancia Josefina is a little over 45 miles (75km) almost due north from El Chaltén, but the route is mostly off road or transfer by private boat. Alternatively, you can arrange a wonderful hike that takes you right up to the estancia, but either way, by the time you reach your destination you’ll truly have unplugged from the world: this area is so remote even the indigenous Tehuelche people didn’t live here. This is estancia offers a rustic small farm experience, with accommodation consisting of just four glamping dome tents. There are plenty of rescue animals here (the food is great for vegetarians and vegans).

Name: Estancia La Estela
Description: Situated roughly halfway between El Chaltén and El Calafate (and less than two hours’ drive from either). Estancia La Estela sits on a rise above La Leona river with tremendous views out across Lago Viedma to the great peaks of the Fitz Roy Massif. La Estela is more boutique guesthouse than true estancia. It doesn’t offer a true authentic ranch experience but more than makes up for that with its breathtaking setting and clutch of five luxe suites. Horseriding, trail walking and mountain bike riding are all available, but one of the other big draws here is the food. La Estela’s restaurant is simply incredible and the owners are planning a covered vineyard to produce Patagonia’s most southerly wine.

Name: Estancia La Peninsula
Description: Occupying 19,000 hectares between two of Chilean Patagonia's defining landscapes, the pampa and the fjords, the remote Estancia La Peninsula is one of only two estancias on the Antonio Veras Peninsula. Reached only by a 30-minute boat journey from Puerto Natales, a true Patagonian experience is to be had - look forward to daily Patagonian barbecues and sheep-shearing demonstrations. Among the range of excursions are treks, including a two- to four-day hike, horseback riding, and a 4x4 ride to Cerro Ballena (Whale Hill). Overnight stays are possible at the newly renovated countryside cabin, affectionately named 'La Barrosa', nestled 8km from the main estancia houses.
What we like about this hotel:
• Only accessible by a 30-minute boat ride from Puerto Natales, it maintains a truly remote atmosphere away from the crowds in Torres del Paine.
  • They offer daily sheep-shearing demonstrations and a huge, traditional Patagonian asado for lunch.
  • Sweeping vistas as far as the eye can see with looming glacier-capped mountains and dazzling reflections from the fjords.
  • It's a place where time slows down...
We think its worth noting: • You can’t stay in the Estancia itself but at La Barrosa which is located 8km away from the estancia “casco".
What they say about this accommodation: I love being able to unwind and roam on my own schedule here. There are some beautiful riding opportunities. Plus, you can tag along with the dogs who herd and protect the sheep - who are very, very cute!

Name: Estancia Lago Pinto
Description: Estancia Lago Pinto is another historic working ranch, tracing its roots back to the pioneering days of 1890. Today, under the stewardship of Pedro Pivcevic Jara, the estancia has adapted to modern demands by transitioning from sheep to cattle farming, yet it staunchly preserves the rural customs and sustainable practices of its heritage. Guests at Estancia Lago Pinto are treated to an immersive experience of Patagonian life, from authentic barbecues and folk music, to educational tours of the greenhouses and animal enclosures, culminating in hands-on activities like sheep shearing and horseback riding through sweeping historic landscapes.

Name: Estancia Lazo
Description: Estancia Lazo is situated just on the border of Torres del Paine and is part of a huge cattle ranch dating from the last century that now rus 32,000 acres (13,000 hectares). It boasts magnificent views over Laguna Verde as well as the Paine Massif. The rooms are simple yet comfortable. The main estancia house and dining room-cum-bar are great to relax in after a day of riding in the park. The estancia also has a complete house for up to eight people that can be booked for exclusive stays.

Name: Estancia Nibepo Aike
Description: Located just over an hours’ drive from El Calafate, Estancia Nibepo Aike is one of the best places in the region to get a real taste of the gaucho lifestyle. Established in 1912, this working estancia still raises both sheep and cattle. Its rooms are comfortable and spacious, and are decorated with black and white photos detailing a century of family frontier history. Nibebo Aike’s proximity to Perito Moreno glacier and its deeply authentic vibe make this a popular estancia, where you can expect real gaucho culture on display, from sheep shearing to traditional barbecues. To explore the landscapes around the estancia, horse riding is available, as well as hiking and mountain bike trails.
What we like about this hotel:
• Experience an authentic working estancia in Los Glaciares National Park with sheep, cattle and horses all managed on the grounds.
  • The estancia's location is a huge draw, being just over an hour away from El Calafate. Get off the beaten track with little effort or time expended.
  • It's a great place for beginners to horse ride with Patagonian gauchos and is also suited to more experienced riders with some epic multi-day rides on offer.
  • The property is nestled in a quiet valley with stunning scenery all around. Hiking up the mountain behind the estancia presents incredible views over Lago Roca, snow-capped mountains and a hanging glacier; continue a little further and explore a peaceful lenga tree forest at the top.
  • With just 10 rooms and a charmingly laid-back atmosphere, you can expect complete relaxation and peace in your surroundings.
We think its worth noting:
• This estancia is close to one of the most popular landmarks in Patagonia (Perito Moreno Glacier) and it receives a high volume of daytrippers.
  • The day trip from El Calafate is fun and you will get a taste of Patagonian Estancia, but it's not the most authentic.
  • If you would like an authentic experience, then spend the night at Nibepo Aike or ask us about other estancias in the area.
  • There are not that many vegetarian or vegan options on the menu.
What they say about this accommodation: This is the only real 'working Estancia' in the area. It's comfortable, cosy and exclusive. It's also an ideal base for heading on the remarkable Hidden Glaciers riding trip.

Name: Estancia Peuma Hue
Description: Inside the Nahuel Huapi National Park, Argentina's oldest Estancia Peuma Hue lies at the heart of the Argentinean Lake District. Conveniently located near Bariloche, but with a unique, remote feel, this lovely lakeside lodge is our favourite full-board property in the area. Puema Hue offers a multi-activity holiday against a backdrop of relaxing lakes and forested mountainsides.
What they say about this accommodation: Peuma Hue's privileged location means you can hike the self-guided trails at your own pace, when you desire and probably not see another person during the whole time. This is a unique feature compared with other lake-district lodges and hotels. I was lucky enough to sit and watch Magellanic woodpeckers at work (the world's largest woodpecker) on my recent visit there. What a privilege!

Name: Estancia Rincon Chico
Description:
The hotel has 8 rooms, all with private bathrooms. They can be set up as singles, twins or doubles depending on your preference. There is also the option of a cottage.

Stays are a minimum of 3 nights.
What they say about this accommodation: If you're looking for the perfect combination of remote wilderness, comfort, history and wildlife then Rincon Chico is for you. I recommend visiting between September and November for the most diverse wildlife viewing opportunities: Southern Right Whales, Orcas, Sea Lions and Elephant Seals!

Name: Estancia San Luis
Description: Estancia San Luis, managed by the devoted Cárdenas-Oyarzún family for over 45 years, blends traditional livestock farming with the allure of Patagonian cultural tourism across its 32,00 acres (13,000 hectares). Visitors can engage with nature via horseback riding, exploring the estate's diverse landscapes and abundant wildlife, and stay at the Puesto Rio Vizcachas, a charmingly refurbished house near the Argentinian border. This destination offers a genuine slice of Patagonian life, complete with stunning views, local cuisine, and a tranquil atmosphere made for adventure and relaxation in equal measure.

Name: Estancia Tercera Barranca
Description: This family-run working estancia treats its guests with breathtaking views of Torres del Paine’s iconic granite towers and the eastern side of the Paine Massif. The ranch continues to function as a sheep farm, running livestock across its 16,000 acres (6500 hectares). Its seven rooms are all in the converted farmhouse and may be simple but are perfectly cosy. In the evenings you can unwind by the fireplace in the lounge or enjoy meeting other travellers by the barbecue. The hosts provide a warm friendly atmosphere, and there are varied activities on offer here, including horse riding excursions that offer the chance for some great birdwatching.

Name: Explora Atacama
Description: Explora built their reputation upon being the first luxury hotel group to move into Patagonia and have since expanded to include the Atacama in northern Chile. They offer the largest range of excursions for active travellers, including hiking, horseriding and biking, and have the best observtory in San Pedro - their astral tours are awe-inspiring. The four large swimming pools provide fantastic relaxation after a day's adventuring.
Meals Available: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner, Snacks, Box Lunch
What we like about this hotel:
• The first 5-star, all-inclusive luxury hotel in San Pedro de Atacama.
  • They have four infinity pools (plus a sauna).
  • A fantastic variety of excursions for active people who want to be out every day, hiking, biking and riding.
  • Ideal for horseriders as the hotel has its own horses and an amazing stable block.
  • The best telescopic observatory in San Pedro de Atacama.
  • Just 5-10 minutes walk from downtown San Pedro.
  • Puritama hot springs! Explora has a private pool there.
We think its worth noting:
• The pool area is about a 5-7 minute walk away from the rooms. It is a big property so expect lots of walking (on wood platforms and uneven cobblestones).
  • The dining area is more casually designed than expected.
What they say about this accommodation: From leisure overland tours to see once in a lifetime marvels, to advanced horseback riding, high altitude volcano ascents and technical mountain bike rides – Explora has something for everyone. The awe-inspiring astral tours are not to be missed either.

Name: Explora Easter Island
Description: Explora Rapa Nui is the luxury lodge on Easter Island, designed to immerse you in the island’s rich culture and dramatic landscapes. Perched on a secluded hillside with sweeping views of the Pacific, the hotel offers guided explorations, gourmet dining, and sustainable luxury, making it an ideal base for discovering the island’s enigmatic moai and vibrant Polynesian heritage.

Name: Explora El Chaltén
Description: This stunning luxury lodge is nestled in the Los Huemules Reserve to the North of El Chaltén and borders Los Glaciares National Park. From here you can enjoy views of the Electric Valley and the Marconi Glacier. Explora is a contemporary yet rustic lodge, influenced by traditional estancia designs and boasts delectable cuisine, a spa and stunning guided excursions.
Meals Available: Breakfast, Lunch, Box Lunch, Dinner, Snacks
What we like about this hotel:
• The lodge is snug and homely, the staff are warm and welcoming, and it feels like you’re tucked away in the forest as you sit in the living room looking out at the trees, rivers and mountains.
  • This is an adventure lodge set up for adventurers to have a comfy base to explore from: you can hike all day or there is the possibility of high mountain explorations and rock climbing (top rope) for the extreme adventurer.
  • Being in the Los Huemules Reserve, with 5,800 hectares of flora and fauna conservation, you have access to an enormous number of self-guided trails. Plus, you can head out slightly further afield with your guides to explore Mount Fitz Roy.
  • Superb pastries, hearty meat dishes and overall delicious food. 
  • Explora's team act as custodians of the land they have been entrusted with (and have developed) a strict environmental policy.
We think its worth noting:
• There is not much to do if you are not looking for an active adventure or you don't want to go out on a rainy day.
  • When the lodge is at full capacity, space at the spa may be limited. 
  • Only the Suites contain full baths, the other rooms come with showers only.
  • Some rooms have a better view and some can be a little noisy: enquire to find out more. 
  • The external appearance of the lodge may not be as aesthetically attractive as other lodges in the region, but it is pragmatic given the strict sustainability and construction regulations.
What they say about this accommodation: Explora El Chaltén's location in the Los Huemules Reserve is truly secluded and at one with nature. It allows you to step away from busy modern life and reconnect with the natural world on an epic scale.

Name: Explora Torres del Paine
Description: Explora is Torres del Paine’s original luxury lodge and is the only one located inside the boundaries of the national park, overlooked by the famous Towers. There are 49 rooms and suites offering maximum solitude, as well as a restaurant with breathtaking views and a lakeside private spa. The lodge’s location makes it perfectly placed to offer the widest variety of excursions in the park, from hiking the endless trails to horse riding with gauchos from Explora’s own stables. Explora also has its own private boat to explore the park, including direct access to the French Valley trailhead. Explora Patagonia: Essential information: Located in the centre of Torres del Paine National Park, close to the the most popular hiking trails - Wide variety of daily excursions - Access to trailheads courtesy of the lodge’s private boat - Private stables offer fantastic horse riding - The only lodge to remain open all year, with a special winter programme
Meals Available: Breakfast, Lunch, Box Lunch, Dinner, Snacks
What we like about this hotel:
• It’s the best-located hotel in Torres del Paine: in the heart of the park with everything on your doorstep.
  • There are spectacular views of the Paine Massif, particularly striking at sunrise and sunset.
  • It offers more unique facilities than other lodges: a private catamaran takes you directly to the French Valley trailhead and towards Grey Glacier; it has its own stables and specially-bred horses, and hot tubs line the shore of Lake Pehoé.
  • There are the most expansive and varied excursions of any all-inclusive hotel in the park.
  • The guides are fantastic. They're well-trained to deliver safe and exciting experiences for our clients. 
  • It’s the only luxury hotel to open all year round. Winter trips where you can explore the park covered in snow with few guests around offer an incredible and intimate experience.
We think its worth noting:
• The food is not quite at the same level as some other luxury lodges in Torres del Paine.
  • Bathroom facilities are a little dated. 
  • The spa is a two-minute walk from the main building.
What they say about this accommodation: The Explora’s location is truly spectacular, I felt like I could reach out and touch the massif. I loved the nooks and crannies of the lounge area, with lots of places to enjoy a fire, a glass of wine and, of course, the view.

Name: Explora Patagonia National Park
Description: Deep in the Patagonia National Park is a luxury lodge that feels like an Oxford college set in the middle of Patagonia. This stunning lodge is constructed with quarried stone from the valley. Recycled wood has been dutifully handcrafted to make high ceiling beams, floors, door and window frames and furniture throughout and amazing wood carvings of the local wildlife, every piece polished and a perfect fit. Stay in the lodge for total tranquillity and comfort; a little oasis amongst the swaying grasses with hardly another soul (there only six rooms) – just views of grazing guanacos and the craggy peaks beyond.
Meals Available: Breakfast, Lunch, Box Lunch, Dinner, Snacks
What we like about this hotel:
• You're right in the heart of the serene Patagonia National Park.
  • Guanacos on your doorstep give a safari sensation. Plus, there are chances to see pumas, nandu, foxes, hares and huemul deer if you go looking (and keep very quiet).
  • The main lodge was built by craftsmen with incredible wooden carvings, hardwood floors and deep armchairs where you can disappear with a book. 
  • Lovely large bedroom with potentially the most comfortable beds in Chile.
  • The hiking nearby is fantastic: head up to a ridge to take in the panoramas, gaze at condors, and marvel at the volume of water drained off the Northern Ice Field.
  • Fresh, flavourful food including a featured item from the open grill and wonderful veggies from the garden.
  • You can witness the work of the Tompkins Foundation firsthand, with its pioneering conservation impact. The on-site museum is a must too. 
  • Service is highly bespoke and personalised, which aligns with the intimate, boutique nature of the property.
We think its worth noting:
• There is not much infrastructure in the area beyond the lodge itself.
  • Only 3 of the 13 rooms have bathtubs - the Suites in the smaller building.
  •  The parking lot is shared with day tours and guests which could be frustrating during high season. 
  • Horse riding excursions are not allowed in the park.
What they say about this accommodation: There is a family of puma living in the valley near the hotel. When I went on a walk, searching for them, one strolled past the dining room window, making themselves right at home.

Name: French Domes
Description: Small but perfectly formed, the French Domes (Domes el Francés) are a unique stop near the entrance to French Valley on the W Trek. Rather than huts, accommodation here is made up of three domes with bunk beds to sleep eight, plus their own private bathroom and central heating. The location at Camping Francés offers amazing views of Nordenskjold Lake, the Cuernos and Paine Grande. The French Domes are approximately an hour's trek west of Refugio Los Cuernos.

Name: Futangue Hotel
Description: Futangue is a new hotel and nature reserve seated at the foot of the Andes in Chile's Lake District. Experience the volcanic Puyehue National Park and the biodiversity of the Valdivian rainforest, and roam 110 kilometres of quiet trails of spectacular fauna, untouched flora, mesmerising lakes, and ancient forests.
What we like about this hotel:
• Host to a secluded network of 110km of trails, based within the Valdivian rainforest, and just outside of the volcanic Puyehue National Park, the scope for out-of-this-world type adventuring is phenomenal.
  • Located in Futangue Park, it’s more remote and less crowded than many other options, but it’s still well-connected, with a transfer from Santiago in just three hours, and the opportunity to combine with trips from Puerto Varas to Pucón.
  • Unique and elegant in design, Futangue's exterior is characterised by native wood, while the large communal interior spaces celebrate national artists and the Mapuche culture.
  • Embrace nature photography opportunities, trek or bike in lush meadows and forests, or pass the magical islands of Lake Ranco navigating by kayak or boat.
  • There are great spa facilities with an outdoor lap pool, indoor/outdoor jacuzzi and plenty of lounging areas around the entire hotel.
We think its worth noting:
• You have to walk either through the restaurant or around the building to get to the spa.
  • It is remote—with nothing around—so you would need a car to get to the town about an hour and a half away.
What they say about this accommodation: There’s a huge network of trails in the park that offer fantastic hiking and biking. There’s even a special trail for Darwin frogs, but we saw plenty of them even in areas where they weren’t expected.

Name: Green Baker Lodge
Description: Green Baker Lodge sits among trees just south of Puerto Bertrand on the banks of the Baker River. The lodge is a convenient place to stay consisting of a central guesthouse with five cosy bedrooms and seven simple, comfortable cabins accommodating two to seven people in each. Cabins have their own kitchens, bathrooms and wooden decked terraces. Furniture is made from red Rauli wood, native to the area. Try a hot tub on the riverbank or use the zipline to whizz across the river.

Name: Home Hotel
Description: Your stylish Buenos Aires escape waits. Relax by the outdoor pool, unwind in the garden, or visit the spa. Choose from cool, comfortable rooms - some with spa baths and city views. Start your day with a delicious breakfast with fresh juices, croissants, and homemade treats. The hotel restaurant offers international cuisine and local flavours, plus their famous daily brunch. The trendy Serrano Square craft fair is a 10-block walk, and there's a polo court 12 blocks away.

Name: Hospedaje La Casona
Description: After winding your way down the switchbacks heading south on the Carretera Austral from the Cerro Castillo mountain range, you take a left at the first junction to arrive at this simple, homely guesthouse just off the main route. Wonderful mountain views and rolling fields await you at La Casona, run by your friendly host, Mary. Just 10 minutes' drive away in Villa Cerro Castillo you can find a few small shops and restaurants. Make the most of the stunning scenery by following trekking trails, exploring on horseback or just relaxing in this bucolic setting. It's a perfect for road trippers and hikers alike.

Name: Hostal Gladys
Description: Great for backpackers, Hostal Gladys has good wifi, comfy beds, great showers and a decent sized breakfast. The decor is more than a little dated and some rooms are poky with no windows, but the staff are friendly and the prices are low.

Name: Hostería El Paraíso
Description: This hostería has a cosy and welcoming feel with a small bar. The rooms are basic and simply decorated. It's located close to the bars, restaurants and other amenities. The views of Mt Fitz Roy on a clear day are simply breathtaking.

Name: Hotel Almasur
Description: Hotel Almasur, previously the 'Rey Don Felipe', is set back a little from the hustle and bustle of the centre on a quiet road, but still only a five-minute walk from the main square of Punta Arenas and the Strait. A 4-star refurbished classic of the city, it's a comfortable and convenient resting spot. The helpful staff will ease the stress of travelling and recommend some great eateries nearby. There is Wi-Fi throughout the hotel, as well as a gym and a spa. The breakfast is very good too!

Name: Hotel Ancud
Description: Hotel Ancud, located on the outskirts of Chiloé's second city, Ancud, brings to life a magnificent building and one of the most beautiful places in the northern Chilean Patagonia. A breathtaking view of the bay and peninsula Lacuy, expect it to provide a pleasant and magical break.

Name: AWA
Description: A luxurious hotel located around 25 minutes from the town centre. The property, nestled on the shores of Lago Llanquihue, boasts unbeatable views to the mighty Osorno Volcano when the skies are clear. It is conveniently placed for most of the main excursions in the area, such as the Desolacion hike and the Petrohué Falls. The design of the hotel is perhaps not to everyone's taste, but is certainly unique with plenty of exposed concrete externally and internally, a mixture of modern art and traditional crafts. With just 16 rooms, booking in advance is highly recommended.
What they say about this accommodation: AWA gives you luxury and quality in every sense. It has a super modern feel with huge windows, king-size beds and impressive decor. I loved the spa and communal areas to sit watching the sun go down.

Name: Hotel Babel Boutique
Description: Hotel Babel is located in a 200 year old building in the San Telmo district just a stone’s throw from Plaza Dorega. It's combination of old and new features creates a very funky but comfortable setting. The reception is hung with paintings from their artist in residence. A role given to emerging artists who each take a month long turn. The nine rooms are on the ground and first floor, set around a courtyard. Each room has an ensuite bathroom with hot powerful shower and  plenty of mirrors. Suite rooms have king-size bed whilst standard rooms have queen-size.

Name: Hotel Bidasoa
Description: A beautiful and welcoming boutique hotel located near some great restaurants and cafés in a quiet and relaxing part of Santiago. The hotel boasts 87 spacious and well-lit rooms with a homely feel, friendly service from its staff, and ample and verdant outdoor space with a pool for relaxing in the heat of a Santiago summer. Bidasoa is very proud of its sustainable principles and excellent vegan food.

Name: Hotel Cabaña del Lago
Description: Hotel Cabana del Lago is a family-owned company which since 1980 has grown into one of the leading hotels in the area, which reassures customs and typical German traditions that give a unique character to Puerto Varas. It has 157 guest rooms all with guaranteed views of Lake Llanquihue and the nearby Osorno and Calbuco volcanoes. There is a heated pool making it great for families and relaxing.

Name: Hotel Clásico
Description: Set across the street from the main hub of restaurants of Palermo Hollywood, this is a quirkily designed boutique hotel without the price tag of other upmarket accommodation. It has small, functional but characterful rooms, enthusiastic owners and a great breakfast. A great option for guests looking for a little bit of Buenos Aires character without too much luxury and a great location for evening entertainment.

Name: Hotel Cumbres Lastarria
Description: This a large and modern hotel offering 70 rooms. You can enjoy views of the city from both its restaurant and terrace pool. It's a very comfortable place to stay in this bohemian neighbourhood, surrounded by restaurants, museums and theatres.

Name: Hotel Diego de Almagro
Description: Comfortable and convenient - the hotel is located on the shores of the Strait of Magellan with an impressive view of the Pacific Ocean. Rooms are spacious and can have either a city or sea view. Take advantage of facilities such as a gym, swimming pool/sauna, and business centre suitable for hosting meetings or events.

Name: Hotel Director
Description: This hotel offers 96 spacious rooms with contemporary minimalist decor in a great location in Vitacura. As well as the excellent service, you can enjoy cooling off in the outdoor pool or unwinding in the sauna. Rooms have views of the mountains and city and some are specially designed for people with reduced mobility.

Name: Hotel Dreams
Description: The modern one of the bunch, Hotel Dreams is characterised by its glassy architecture and bustling, large hotel feel. There is a clear emphasis on fun with live evening performances, a fantastic Sky Bar on the eleventh floor and the southernmost casino in the world (in Chile, at least). Guests can also relax in the hydra spa and swim in the infinity swimming pool which flaunts the hotel's privileged views of the Strait of Magellan and Tierra del Fuego and the Mirador Hill ski slopes beyond.

Name: Hotel Grey
Description: Look out through floor-to-ceiling windows onto icebergs as they float down the magnificent Lago Grey. In the distance is the Southern Ice Cap and Paine Massif, which descend down to the lake forming the famous Glacier Grey. These are arguably the best views of any hotel in the park, and they continue in the superior rooms where the windows are just as large as in the dining areas. Boat excursions across the lake start here, and just behind the hotel is the trailhead to Mirador Ferrier, the one place nearby that you'll get even better views than in the hotel. Combine Hotel Grey with Hotel Las Torres on a self-drive trip, or use it as a final night stop off in the park after completing the W Trek.

Name: Hotel Kran Kreen
Description: A great budget option for travellers who want to be well-located between the main square and the cemetery and not too far from some good restaurants and the Strait of Magellan. The rooms are compact, but perfect for a short stay in the city and with the friendly hotel staff, you'll feel well looked after.

Name: Hotel Ladera
Description: This hotel is in a great location at the foot of San Cristobal Hill. It's close to many bars and restaurants and only a short walk from the metro station. Sleekly designed, its 36 rooms are practical and well-equipped, and the sun terrace and rooftop pool provide a welcome break from the Santiago heat during summer. It's a great value option for travellers to Santiago, especially those who will be out exploring the city for most of the day.

Name: Hotel Las Marianas
Description: A clean and spacious B&B just a 10-minute walk from the town centre. You may find the rooms are a little cramped, but so close to town, you won't be spending much time there. Plus, you'll wake up to a popular breakfast that includes a selection of cereals and tasty homemade cakes.

Name: Hotel Las Torres
Description: Hotel Las Torres occupies one of the best locations in the park, right at the trailhead for the famous Base of the Towers hike. This makes it the perfect base for a day hike, and a great choice on a self-guided W Trek or self-drive trip. The rooms are amply sized, there's a great bar area, a busy restaurant and cosy lounges. The hotel also has a team of horses which create quite a stir in the morning and evening when the gauchos bring them in from higher pastures. The hotel is quite large and in a busy part of the park, so lacks the exclusiveness and tranquillity of more luxurious options, but stands up as a good mid-range option.
What we like about this hotel:
• The hotel’s location is in the heart of the National Park at the trailhead for the hike to the Tower's viewpoint.
  • Wake up to horses roaming past your windows. With about 200 horses stabled on-site, you’ll get to experience a working Patagonian estancia.
  • The only hotel in the national park with such a deep-rooted history; learn about the pioneering family who settled here and built the first hotel in the area.
  • An accomplished team of resident guides will help you explore and learn about the national park’s flora, fauna and history in small-group outings.
  • The new waterfall-style showers are fabulous.
  • Good food with more choice than many all-inclusive accommodations and guests order from it a la carte. We love the omelette bar at breakfast and the quincho for an asado BBQ.
We think its worth noting:
• The recent renovation has given the rooms a more modern and minimalistic feel that is in contrast with the cosy estancia feel of the communal rooms. 
  • This is a big hotel and wouldn't be right for people looking for a boutique experience. 
  • There may not be much lounge space at peak times for such a big hotel so you are either in your room or the busy bar.
  • Excursions need to be booked before you arrive or at check-in which gives you less flexibility than other all-inclusive hotels.
  • The Lago Grey boat trip is not included as standard and needs to be booked in advance.
What they say about this accommodation: One of the best located hotels in the world, Las Torres retains much of its founding heritage, and is akin to staying at both a pioneer’s estancia and a fantastic hotel all in one. Old photos on the walls, gauchos rounding up the horses, and the friendly greeting of the staff, make this hotel a truly unique place to stay in Torres del Paine.

Name: Hotel Los Ponchos
Description: Swoop's favourite Calafate hotel. A Poncho is a native garment for both warmth and protection, and this hotel in El Calafate offers this and more. A stylish boutique hotel with an elegant rustic charm, it's a great option for those wanting to be well looked after during their time in Patagonia. The hosts make sure your stay is cozy and relaxing, with breakfast being served either in the restaurant or in your room if you prefer. Located just far enough away from the centre to be peaceful, and with wonderful access to Lake Argentino, yet within walking distance to the shops and restaurants of the centre of town.

Name: Hotel Luciano K
Description: This option mixes character and original charm with a modern twist in a fun neighbourhood a stone's throw from Santa Lucia Hill. The staff are friendly and helpful. There's a rooftop bar, decent food and a (tiny) pool. It's a good choice for those looking for a lower-end boutique hotel. The homemade breakfasts are a great addition too.

Name: Hotel Malalhue
Description: A family hotel with 24 rooms and 15 years of history in the town of Pucón, in a central location to discover the wonderful experiences that this area offers. The hotel has a warm and friendly atmosphere with a particular mountain style, which is known for its woods and local materials. It has a delicate, fresh and welcoming atmosphere, where you will find rest, comfort and good service.

Name: Hotel Pehoe
Description: The simple but comfortable Hotel Pehoe sits in an unrivalled position in the national park, on an island on the Pehoe Lake. It is one of the oldest hotels in the park so is rather tired in places and the furnishings could be described as traditional. It makes an interesting base for one night if doing a self-drive through the park, but don't expect fine dining or any type of luxury.

Name: Hotel Peninsula Valdés
Description: A contemporary mid-range hotel in an excellent location in the heart of town, right on the sea front, with panoramic views of the Golfo Nuevo. It is just a few minutes' walk from the beach, and has a spa, gym and bar.

Name: Hotel Puelche
Description: Hotel Puelche enjoys a great location near the centre of Puerto Varas. The hotel exterior is typical of many traditional buildings in the area and inside there's a boutique feel with just 21 rooms. The warm and friendly ambience, plus the high level of comfort, make this an ideal place to relax and unwind after a day of adventure in the outdoors. There's also a fantastic gourmet burger bar which serves local beers!

Name: Hotel Rio Serrano
Description: Located in the Pueblito Serrano on the southern edge of the national park, this hotel has breathtaking views of the whole Paine Massif, with the winding Serrano River in the foreground. As it is located almost in the centre of the park, it makes a great self-drive base if you don't want to move accommodation or as a mid-range all-inclusive option. There are estancias in this area of the park, which makes it a good base for horse riding.
What they say about this accommodation: Rio Serrano is popular with groups so has a lively atmosphere, but is a big step up from some of the budget and mid-range accommodation options in Torres del Paine, and the views of the Cuernos will take your breath away...

Name: Hotel Solace
Description: Located near the metro, this 4-star hotel has 108 uniquely-styled modern and spacious rooms. The highlight is undoubtedly its rooftop terrace with a pool and bar, providing one of the best places to see the sunset and the city’s stunning skyline. With a noteworthy in-house Mediterranean restaurant, this modern hotel is both comfortable and great value for your time in Santiago.

Name: Hotel Ultimo Paraiso
Description: Ultimo Paraiso is our top hotel choice in Cochrane – a homely place to stay just two blocks from Cochrane's main square. This hotel has everything you need for a very comfortable stay in this little town. Wooden cladding inside and out give it a real mountain lodge feel. It has seven rooms for up to three people in each and all have modern en suite bathrooms. For breakfast, help yourself to a buffet of cereals, breads, cakes, fruits, cheeses and meats. Close to Patagonia National Park's Chacabuco Valley, the San Lorenzo and San Valentin mountains and the Baker River, there's plenty to do here for nature lovers.

Name: Hotel Veat
Description: A minimalistic hotel incorporating solar energy and with a strong sustainable ethos. It is located in the centre of town and provides a warm and relaxed atmosphere with 15 modern-styled rooms that are functional and filled with light. The hotel’s restaurant, Santolla, is proud to serve many vegan dishes as part of its menu. In addition, the property features a sauna, a wooden outdoor jacuzzi and magnificent views of the surrounding landscape.

Name: Intersur
Description: Large, functional and well-located, the Intersur is a good lower cost option in Recoleta, which offers clean, spacious and private rooms. If you are looking for a central base and a quiet place to stay this hotel is a great option - it has everything that you'd expect of a hotel of this standard.

Name: Italiano
Description: Italiano is one of three campsites in Torres del Paine maintained by CONAF, the national park authority. It's not in proximity to any refugios, so you have nature all to yourself. When operating, the campsite must be booked in advance. Only simple facilities are on offer: wood platforms for pitching tents, cooking shelter and a long-drop toilet. There are no showers.

Name: Japones
Description: Japones is a remote campsite with no facilities and only a limited number of pitches. It can only be used when booked in advance with CONAF (the national park authority) and when hiking with a guide.

Name: Jose Nogueira
Description: Situated right on the main square, this hotel is in a fantastic central location, just five minutes walk from the main street of restaurants and cafes, the bus station and the port. It has a slightly less polished feel than the other upmarket hotels in the town but is in a beautiful old building with more character than the other upmarket options.

Name: Kaulem
Description: This four-bedroom boutique hotel, with views of Fitz Roy from your room and breakfast table, feels like a home away from home. It is ideal for a small group of 6-8 people with a cosy sitting room and floor to ceiling glass so you really feel a connection with the mountains, even when indoors. They also serve a mean breakfast that will turbo-power you into the hills.

Name: Kimal
Description: Absolutely central is the three-star boutique Kimal - akin to a small and charming adobe village where the bedrooms are individual huts. They have a simple spa, something which most other hotels in this category don't have. For those on a budget who want comfort in a central location, this place is ideal.

Name: Kosten Aike
