Description: The incredibly friendly staff and playroom (table football, pool and table tennis) make the Kosten Aike a good, comfortable hotel for families and groups. Its location just 200m from the main street makes it great for eating out nearby and for visiting the local artisan shops. It's not the quietest of El Calafate's hotels, but certainly great value for money.

Name: La Casa de Eugenia
Description: Set in the mountain town of San Martin de los Andes, this hotel is within easy reach of Lake Lacar and is a comfortable base for trekking, fly-fishing and all the other activities available in this region. Facilities in the rooms are good, and dinner can be found in one of a selection of restaurants within a few minutes' walk of the hotel.

Name: La Cascada
Description: This is a good option for people who want to stay in a nice area with great 180-degree views of Nahuel Huapi Lake. It's outside of Bariloche so is much quieter than being in town and there is a bus which you can catch close to the hotel. They have comfortable beds, very friendly staff and a nice garden/grounds/beach. There are also opportunities to relax with a sauna, indoor pool and wine bar on site.

Name: La Ernestina
Description: Estancia La Ernestina is located on private land at Punta Norte, where the orcas come to hunt sea lion pups in March/April. The estancia has a private penguin colony with over 140,000 pairs, as well as sea lions, southern right whales and elephant seals on it's coastline. Open from from 1st March to 10th May and 1st October to 1st December.

Name: La Estepa
Description: A great budget option for your time in El Calafate, this hotel is one of the furthest from town and wonderfully immersed in the steppe scenery, just as its name suggests. This cozy country lodge hotel is simple yet comfortable and is within walking distance from the Glaciarium museum. Town is a short taxi ride away, but with the in-house restaurant serving tasty food, you may prefer to stay and enjoy the uninterrupted views of the lake.

Name: La Factoría Park
Description: At La Factoria, the accommodation is a mountain refuge with 3 shared bedrooms, 2 shared bathrooms, a common area with a kitchen, wood stove and nice views to the fjord. It is comfortable and clean.

Name: Las Balsas Relais & Châteaux
Description: Located on the shores of Lake Lacar, this luxurious boutique hotel offers views of the lake and surrounding mountains. It features elegant accommodations, fine dining, and a focus on personalized service, making it a serene getaway for those looking to explore the natural beauty of Patagonia while being close to the charming town of San Martín. While it's farther from Bariloche — about 120 km (75 miles) — Las Balsas is ideally positioned for guests wishing to enjoy the tranquillity of the region.

Name: Las Hayas
Description: Tucked into the forested hills above Ushuaia, Las Hayas offers spacious rooms with sweeping views. The spa is big, well-equipped, and the indoor pool is excellent. There are plenty of activities to book—both free and paid—and the staff are all helpful and friendly. If you’re looking to be surrounded by green and mountains, away from the city, it’s a great spot. It also comes in at around 50% of the cost of Arakur or Cauquenes.

Name: Las Lengas
Description: For an economic option in Ushuaia, Las Lengas provides a comfortable place to base yourself during your stay in the city. The Rooms are compact and very modern, with the main attraction being the public areas and bar with magnificent views over the Beagle Channel. Remodelled about 10 years ago, this hotel boasts a contemporary energy-efficient construction and design and is a 5 minute walk from most attractions and restaurants.

Name: Le Chatelet Hotel
Description: This friendly and comfortable hotel in the heart of San Martin de los Andes has rooms which overlook the surrounding mountains. Use Le Chatelet Hotel as a base for exploring the region's lakes and mountains, or come here to relax in the peaceful surroundings and enjoy the hotel's spa facilities and treatments.

Name: Le Reve Hotel
Description: This boutique hotel, strategically located in central Providencia, near the metro and many restaurants and shops, is an ideal base for visitors to the city. Le Reve combines French architecture with a contemporary style, making it very appealing. With over 30 rooms, some overlooking the interior garden, and all equipped with air-conditioning and a full set of amenities, this hotel suits all types of travellers.

Name: Legado Mitico
Description: This luxury hotel offers a unique experience. With just nine rooms, it offers a very intimate, peaceful experience. The hotel rooms all have different names (rather than numbers) and themes. One of the rooms is called 'La Primer Dama' ('The First Lady'), a room themed around Evita Peron. The touches are subtle and include photos of her life, a cabinet above the bath of replica possessions and a bodice with pearls above the fireplace. There is a spacious outside terrace on the ground level and a sun deck on the roof. The hotel is located close to bars, restaurants and the subway.

Name: Llao Llao Resort
Description: A renowned luxury retreat nestled in the Lake District, 15 miles from Bariloche. Surrounded by the Andean peaks, lush forests, and the tranquil waters of Lake Nahuel Huapi, the resort is celebrated for its setting and world-class amenities. The property combines rustic charm with refined elegance, offering an 18-hole golf course, a relaxing spa, gourmet dining, and outdoor activities like trekking, skiing, and water sports. We recommend the Moreno Wing rooms, given their more modern and spacious design. If not staying here as a guest we highly recommend heading here for afternoon tea (booking in advance is required).

Name: Loi Suites
Description: Tucked away in this upscale district of Buenos Aires, Loi Suites Recoleta offers a luxurious stay for travellers seeking comfort and a prime location. This 4-star hotel boasts spacious and elegantly decorated rooms, perfect for unwinding after a day of exploring the city. Beyond the plush accommodations, guests can take advantage of the hotel's sparkling indoor pool, a welcome amenity for those seeking relaxation. The hotel's enviable location places you just steps away from the iconic Recoleta Cemetery and a vibrant collection of shops, restaurants, and cultural attractions.

Name: Los Canelos
Description: Set in a charming house overlooking the valley, Los Canelos, is a cosy three-star hosteria, 200m from Calafate Creek. It has a good restaurant and a continental breakfast is provided. Try to take advantage of the sun terrace. There is also a wine bar boasting a wide variety of wines from local and international cellars.

Name: Los Cauquenes Resort
Description: The hotel is one of only a handful of places that sits on the shore of the Beagle Channel and is certainly the most luxurious. From your room, you can gaze across one of the most dramatic stretches of water in Patagonia, enjoying the unique birdlife that frequents these shores and the distant mountains of Isla Navarino. Los Cauquenes is traditional yet comfortable and spacious, and there’s a spa for resting your legs after a day exploring the national park. Just 6km west of Ushuaia, nip into town with an easy 15-minute journey by shuttle bus or taxi.
What we like about this hotel:
• Very tranquil while being just 15 minutes from the centre of town.
  • Fantastic views throughout the resort, afforded by wide windows and a communal glass room enhancing the edge-of-the-earth feel.
  • An authentic Argentine experience with a touch of luxury, great food and fantastic wine lists.
  • Good spa facilities that will be improved later in 2025.
  • Walk along the private beach by dawn, day or dusk and witness the extraordinary birdlife that visits the waters and Isla Navarino mountains.
  • The inviting interior is rustic and homely in style, perfect for reflecting on a day spent on one of the many excursions offered. 
  • It has its own boat! Akawaia is an exclusive vessel for experiences on the Beagle Channel, including wildlife observation tours and gourmet meals aboard.
We think its worth noting:
• We think Cauquenes is suited to someone who prefers smaller hotels / a more boutique style with character. 
  • Standard rooms may not have a view of the mountains/Beagle Channel—so we'd recommend upgrading to one of the premium options.
  • Thin walls in some of the rooms can lead to disruption
  • If you don’t want to take the shuttle (which goes every hour) into town, you are better off choosing somewhere within walking distance. 
  • Rates vary enormously throughout the season.
What they say about this accommodation: During your stay at this resort, you can partake in a range of Swoop’s Ushuaia-based excursions. In addition to these, I really liked the ones onboard the Cauquenes exclusive boat ‘Akawaia’, which is a great premium option for enjoying tours on the Beagle Channel. I also love the fact that you can hike up to Monte Susana from the hotel!

Name: Los Cerros
Description: Located on a high point in the town, Los Cerros has great views of the Las Vueltas river valley and surrounding landscape. There are four room types - all are spacious with simple, stylish decor featuring plenty of exposed wood. There are several comfortable shared areas in the hotel for relaxing. The superb restaurant serves contemporary food from Patagonian products which can be paired with a choice of over 120 wines from the hotel’s cellar.

Name: Los Raices B&B
Description: A great location, with a superb in-house restaurant serving a brilliant breakfast, and very attentive and helpful staff.

Name: Maison Italia 1029
Description: This boutique hotel is located in the Barrio Italia area of Providencia. This relaxed area has numerous Italian restaurants and wine bars centred on Santa Isabel St. The hotel has just six guest rooms, most with private terraces. There is contemporary decor throughout and the well-appointed rooms have WiFi, air-conditioning and safe boxes. On the ground floor is a stylish café serving breakfasts, lunches and snacks.

Name: Mallín Colorado Lodge
Description: Stay in one of Mallin Colorado Lodge's rustic cabins in the woods overlooking Lago General Carrera on your trip along the Carretera Austral. There are four smaller cabins accommodating two to six guests and the newly built Casa Lenga for up to twelve people. Each has a woodburner inside plus private terrace where you can just sit back and soak up the mountain views. It's the ideal base for visiting the Marble Caves, being only 40 minutes by car from the beginning of the excursion. as well as being in prime position to explore the Exploradores Glacier near Laguna San Rafael National Park. Equally, there are some great hiking trails surrounding the lodge to discover.
What we like about this hotel:
• Run by seven brothers and sisters, Mallin Colorado is a home away from home.
  • The location is ideal for exploring the Marble Caves, Patagonia National Park and the best views of the Northern Patagonian Icefield without hiking for very long. 
  • They have 500 hectares of private land - you can hike or horse ride (guided rides are offered daily and included in your stay).
  • Enjoy delicious, home-cooked meals.
  • You have sweeping views of the cerulean blue lake from all angles.
We think its worth noting:
• We wouldn't class it as an Ecolodge, despite some attempts to be more sustainable.
  • The staff could be more proactive with service but friendly if you ask for help.
  • There is no WIFI in the cabins (only in the main lodge).
What they say about this accommodation: You feel like you're a million miles from civilization, and yet you've got comfortable rooms, modern amenities and good food. It's a place to embrace a true off-the-beaten-track experience.

Name: Mandarin Oriental
Description: Experience a slice of luxury at this 5-star hotel in Santiago, celebrated as one of the city's finest. As part of a world-renowned luxury brand, they offer a blend of style and sophistication. Their serene outside gardens and swimming pool with a cascading waterfall create a peaceful escape from the city's vibrant energy. Whether you enjoy fine dining, love amenities like pools and spas, or appreciate exceptional service, this hotel is an excellent choice for your stay in Santiago.

Name: Matetic Vineyard
Description: Why not stay in a beautiful winery estate just 50 miles from Santiago airport? This peaceful all-inclusive retreat is ideal for both wine lovers and those simply wanting some R&R at the end of their adventure. They have a lovely pool and gardens filled with palm trees. You'll have the chance to take a biodynamic tour of the site to see how they make their delicious EQ and Coralillo brands of wine. Their 5-course lunch or dinner with wine pairing served at the Equilibrio Restaurant is not to be missed!
What we like about this hotel:
• Pristine and sun-drenched green grounds—a little slice of heaven—only 90 minutes from Santiago city centre.
  • The wine! Great tastings, winery tours, excursions in the vineyards and of course, wine served with every meal. You can eat, sleep, breathe and drink wine.
  • Lovely, classical rooms both comfortable and large.
  • Top-notch Chilean cuisine, produced locally or grown themselves, served within a unique circular restaurant setting. 
  • Exploring the vineyards on foot, bike and van. 
  • The pool area has double lounge beds with netting plus lounge chairs for extra comfort.
We think its worth noting:
• The aesthetics and decor are not high-end luxury but it has a nice, sophisticated feel. 
  • The reception/wine-selling area could do with a separate space for those coming for the day and those staying at La Casona.
What they say about this accommodation: If you want to rest your weary limbs after more thrilling adventures and hikes down south, I think Matetic is a fantastic option before making your journey home.

Name: Mil810
Description: Located in the heart of town, Mil810 offers a warm and modern atmosphere, ideal for a relaxing escape, for those with simple accommodation expectations. There are excellent, unobstructed views of the Beagle Channel and the snow-capped peaks of the Fuegian Andes (especially from the rooftop restaurant). Reviewers consistently praise the friendly and helpful staff, who make you feel at home. There is 24-hour reception and you're only a few blocks from the main streets of Ushuaia.

Name: Mine Hotel
Description: Located in central Palermo Soho, with just 20 rooms, Mine has a cosy, homely feel but still manages to capture the fun bohemian buzz of Palermo. It has a garden with a pool and also a bar/restaurant that offers a happy hour. The hotel is filled with natural light and is very colourful; the rooms are quite small for a 3-4* hotel but the location and atmosphere outweighs this.

Name: Mirador del Lago
Description: A superb well-located hotel, away from the hustle and bustle the town centre, yet only 500m walk to the downtown area. With ample views over the Lake Argentino, we’d recommend the superior rooms as they’re larger and boast more of a view. The buffet breakfast is one of the best in El Calafate and the spacious communal and garden areas allow for guests to relax outside of their rooms if desired.

Name: Mountain Lodge
Description: With space to sleep just 12 people, this charming little mountain home, makes for a culturally interesting, cosy base to return to after your days out on the trails. There are private rooms, a shared bathroom, hot water and delicious meals served by the lovely Anita. This is a great choice if you are looking for a little more comfort and ease but still a rich hiking experience.

Name: Nayara Alto Atacama
Description: An oasis of calm nestled in the Atacama Desert. Around 3km north of the town centre, Nayara Alto Atacama is a luxurious all-inclusive resort. It stands out for its 'Andescape' philosophy, seeking to fit seamlessly into its surrounding environment in every way possible. Its adobe construction and well-kept desert garden take inspiration from local culture and tradition. You'll enjoy gourmet cuisine and the bar opens to a terrace with fire pits. Rejuvenate in the spa where there are five outdoor swimming pools and two hot tubs all the while surrounded by breathtaking desert landscapes. The hotel also has an excellent location for astral tours due to zero light pollution.

Name: Noi Casa Atacama
Description: Well situated in San Pedro de Atacama, this boutique hotel offers a warm embrace amid the breathtaking scenery of Northern Chile. They have bright, spacious rooms adorned with local touches and luxurious amenities. Wake up to mystical salt flats, fiery volcanoes, and otherworldly rock formations – all from your private terrace! They serve regional cuisine and you can indulge in traditional spa treatments or simply soak up the sun by the pool. NOI Atacama offers a great combination of comfort and luxury under the endless Atacama sky (and stars).

Name: Noi Indigo
Description: Hotel Noi Indigo is a modern boutique spa hotel with views overlooking Last Hope Sound, just a stone's throw from the town. Its open communal spaces, hammocks and roof-top jacuzzis give it a relaxed feel. Enjoy buffet breakfasts and varied evening meals in the modern but cosy restaurant. Rooms are cosy and intimate, with subtle decor, lighting and open-plan bathrooms. The Indigo offers four different types of rooms - Deluxe, Deluxe Superior, Junior Suite and Suite.

Name: Noi Vitacura
Description: A stay at Noi is refined and sophisticated. Relax in the spa, enjoy exquisite dining and experience sunset from the rooftop pool and bar. This hotel feels 5-star, but without the associated price tag, and its modern architecture is an attraction in itself. Situated close to both Bicentenary Park and San Cristobal Hill, you’re never far away from the green lungs of the capital.

Name: Nomades
Description: Nomades mixes modern architecture with rustic art: there are animal skins on the floors and soft furnishings and photos of Tehuelche people on the walls. It gets the best of both worlds in Coyhaique with its perfect location - walk out of the front door and you're minutes from the central square, look out of the bedroom windows and you've got views of the Simpson Reserve and river. Service is relatively hands-off, but if you are happy to be self-sufficient and would rather see the river from your shower than have overly interested hosts, then this is a great choice.

Name: Nothofagus
Description: Just a 10-min walk from the bus station, you'll be made to feel right at home by the accommodating owners of this Swiss chalet-styled B&B. Already good value for a clean and cheerful stay, you can stretch your money even further by choosing one of their rooms that shares a bathroom between two.

Name: Nuss
Description: Located in a converted convent, this 22 room hotel is chic and trendy. It has a rooftop plunge pool and sun deck and is just around the corner from the main bars and restaurants of Palermo Soho. We don't advise staying on a Friday or Saturday night unless you plan to be out with the night owls. It was lovingly restored in 2009 and does an excellent job of combining the classic Spanish style with the modern touches and styles of Buenos Aires.

Name: Oceano Patagonia
Description: An unbeatable location - walk straight on to the beach from your bedroom! This self catering accommodation has stunning views of Pirámides beach, and the ocean flanked by dramatic cliffs in the distance. The accommodation is eco-friendly, and has a small kitchenette and sofa area allowing you to prepare meals at your convenience. Wonderful staff, modern design, clean and comfortable rooms.

Name: Palafito 1326 Hotel Boutique
Description: This boutique hotel, set in a traditional palafito in Castro, offers a glimpse into Chilote culture. Built on wooden stilts over the water, the hotel reflects the island’s heritage, where locals fished from their homes at high tide and collected seashells at low tide. The warm wooden interior and inviting communal spaces—dining room, terrace, and reading room— create a homely atmosphere. The location is perfect for exploring the bay and it’s a 15-minute walk to the main square and UNESCO-listed Franciscan Church. The casino is also nearby. Seaview rooms are recommended to avoid traffic noise. From the rooftop terrace, you can enjoy watching small boats, the changing tides, and local birdlife, including swans and kingfishers. Terraza 1326, the top-floor restaurant, serves good meals with lovely views. Friendly, English-speaking staff and great breakfasts complete the experience.

Name: Palo Santo
Description: This hotel has a modern design with charm and a lovely atmosphere. It was set up by Buenos Aires native Pablo Porolli - who had a dream to build a green hotel in the middle of the city. It's the first sustainable urban hotel in Argentina. Built according to LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) standards, Palo Santo is a responsible hotel with green architecture based on the presence of vertical gardens and a comprehensive environmental program that includes the different branches of sustainable building.

Name: Paradise
Description: An old colonial property, set in beautiful gardens, located just a few minutes' walk from Pirámides beach. The rooms are tastefully decorated and the on-site restaurant is one of the best in town.

Name: Patagonia Camp
Description: Patagonia Camp is located just outside the boundaries of Torres del Paine National Park, overlooking the serene waters of Lake Toro. The camp consists of a series of secluded luxury yurts linked by a raised wooden walkway that weaves its way through the forested slopes overlooking the lake and the Paine massif. A separate restaurant high-end cuisine. Each yurt is finished to the finest standard, with en-suite bathroom and private terrace with lake views. Higher categories come with an outdoor Jacuzzi for true pampering. Patagonia Camp is designed to connect you as closely as possible to the tranquillity of nature, and has helped pioneer some of the highest possible environmental operating standards in Patagonia. Patagonia Camp: Essental information: Located south of Torres del Paine National Park on the shores of Lake Toro - Multiple excursions to choose from daily - Large variety of private or off-the-beaten-track excursions - Paddleboarding, kayaking and fishing can be done independently on the lake - Refined and intimate atmosphere, designed for for those wanting a little more privacy
Meals Available: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner, Snacks, Box Lunch
Inspection Notes 3: When I arrived the manager and all the staff greeted us with open arms and we were made right at home, they were so helpful. After lunch they recommend some self-guided walks we could do inside the 38,000 hectare reserve where the camp is located. I grabbed my camera after an amazing lunch and went for a walk in the forest. I was over the moon to find a chuncho (austral pygmy owl) only a few hundred metres away from the camp. As a birdwatcher this was high on my listy and made my first day so much more special.
What we like about this hotel:
• The relaxed and peaceful location, away from the hustle and bustle of the park.
  • Lie in bed at night and watch the celestial display through the central dome in your yurt roof.
  • All the yurts are private, with your own decking looking over the forest and/or the lake. For real luxury, upgrade to a jacuzzi yurt.
  • A variety of excursions flexible to your needs: physically challenging and gentle. Hike iconic trails and off-the-beaten-track.
  • Partake in small group guided activities or upgrade to private excursions if you wish.
  • The property's private land is filled with trails that you can take on your own to admire the incredible views and get away from the crowds of Torres del Paine.
  • The WIFI internet connection is great, but only available in the restaurant / communal spaces.
We think its worth noting:
• Patagonia Camp is very popular meaning it is often fully booked at peak times in the season.
  • It is at least a 1-hour drive from the main trails so those wanting to see 'the highlight hikes' of Torres del Paine then expect to be in a vehicle for at least 2 hours per day. The passing landscapes are amazing!
  • The wind can be very strong in Torres del Paine and make the yurts flap noisily disturbing sleep. Patagonia Camp do provide earplugs for this.
  • The group excursions need a minimum number of guests to confirm so while your wishes will be taken into account they're not guaranteed to run. If this is an issue then choose private excursions.
  • The Shared Program includes a one-way transfer from/to El Calafate or Punta Arenas for guests staying 4 nights+. You will have to pay extra for one leg of the journey if not wanting to go through Puerto Natales.
What they say about this accommodation: The only trouble with basing yourself at Patagonia Camp to explore Torres del Paine is that the property is so beautiful and serene that you won’t want to leave. If time allows, build in an extra day to sleep in, relax, and immerse yourself in the landscape - or at least in the private jacuzzi!

Name: Patagonia House
Description: A bright, modern boutique hotel located on a hillside high above the busy streets of Coyhaique, you have the sense of being far from the hustle and bustle of the city while being only minutes away. Stay in luxury in this peaceful setting amidst the trees with fantastic views of the Coyhaique valley.

Name: Patagonia Queen
Description: This characteristic Patagonian hotel feels like a ski-lodge and boasts a wonderful location, spacious public spaces and a great games room with a pool table and table tennis. Its 20 rooms are comfortable, a good size and all include a small hot-tub in the bathroom. With very friendly staff, this hotel is always popular with Swoop guests given its short walking distance to the centre. It's also within easy reach of the Laguna Nimez coastal nature reserve.

Name: Patios de San Telmo
Description: With it's labyrinth of outdoor patios and balconies, this hotel is a historic gem and a fascinating look into what life must have been like in the late 1800's. There is a great cafe next door where breakfast is served. It is well located near to the main square of San Telmo and allows for a taste of boutique without the expense.

Name: Peninsula Petit
Description: This cosy hotel is located on San Pedro Peninsula, close to Bariloche, and it makes a good base to return to after a day exploring the Lake District. The rooms here are well-equipped, with stunning views over Nahuel Huapi Lake.

Name: Petrohué Lodge
Description: This hotel is located on the shores of Todos los Santos, nestled in the Andes with the stunning backdrop of snowcapped Volcano Osorno. Petrohué Lodge is an excellent base for fly fishing, hiking, canyoneering, rafting and many other activities that can bring you closer to this magical wilderness. After a day of fresh air, you can relax with a delicious meal and the warmth of a magnificent fireplace with a view to the lake. You can also use their lovely hot tubs (at an additional cost).

Name: Poblado Kimal
Description: The Poblado Kimal is a charming group of adobe and wooden cabins that form what is essentially an annexe of the Kimal (listed above), but it's a little cheaper to stay here due to arrangements such as having to cross the street for your breakfast. It is a pleasant environment featuring clean and cosy cabins with personal mini-terraces.

Name: Posada del Río
Description: This elegant and unique atmosphere has been created with rest and disconnection in mind. Inserted into a private four-hectare park on the banks of the River Trancura, Posada del Río hotel is the ideal place to relax and enjoy nature. The six rooms have forest views and are furnished with stylish pieces, large comfortable beds and modern bathrooms. The plentiful buffet breakfast is served in a spacious, welcoming sitting room where our personalised service speaks for itself.

Name: Posada los Juncos
Description: This lake house is a comfortable base for all the activities the region has to offer. Sitting beside Lago Nahuel Huapi, Posada los Juncos is only a 30-minute drive from Bariloche. The accommodation is in just five rooms, each with its own character and a great view. Good food and wine is served in the dining room.

Name: Puyuhuapi Lodge
Description: Bathe in the natural thermal pools at this secluded lodge perched on the shores of the Puyuhuapi Fjord. Its location makes it the perfect place to stay in order to visit the northern section of Queulat National Park. The scenery doesn't get much more tantalising with the emerald fjord fringed by the deep greens of the temperate rainforest and snow-covered granite peaks rising out of the jungle. For complete isolation, the lodge is only accessible by boat.

Name: Quebrada Verde Cabins
Description: Quebrada Verde offers an exclusive set of 6 cabins minutes from Puerto Varas, next to the shore of Lake Llanquihue and surrounded by native forest.. The cabins use a local architectural style from southern Chile, rustic, but luxurious in its interior with the warmth of different native woods of the place. Located on Route 225 (Road to Ensenada), just 7km. from the centre of the city of Puerto Varas. Next to Lake Llanquihue, under Coihues, Arrayanes and Ulmos. It has a good beach, protected from the south wind plus a nice view of the lake and large green areas that lead into the ravine.

Name: Recoleta Grand
Description: With modern spacious rooms and large reception areas, this hotel, with just 88 rooms, is a great upmarket option in Recoleta. What it lacks in the boutique feel of quirky Palermo hotels it makes up for in its very central location in this sophisticated neighbourhood, just a few minutes walk to the famous Recoleta Cemetery and 9th July Avenue. A great option if you're short of time in this big metropolis and if your stay in Buenos Aires falls at the start of your trip. A real highlight are the wine flavoured complementary toiletries!

Name: Refugia Chiloé
Description: Set high up on a hill, surrounded by rolling countryside, this hotel looks out onto the channels and snow-capped volcanoes surrounding Chiloé Island. Offering daily guided excursions, locally sourced and home-cooked food, an in-house spa and beautiful grounds, this hotel gives you a place of incredible peace and tranquillity to relax after an exciting day experiencing the island.
What we like about this hotel:
• The remote location—Set on a bay overlooking an archipelago of smaller islands—yet convenient transport links.
  • 24 rooms that are warm and cosy with rugs and throws, woven from local lambs wool, as well as jacuzzi bathtubs and panoramic views.
  • Daily choice of excursions on foot, horse, bike, by vehicle, kayak or boat with group sizes limited to eight guests to ensure personal attention.
  • It's steeped in tradition. A journey to Refugia Chiloé is as much about the island's rich and magical culture as it is about its beautiful landscapes.
  • 5* culinary options ensure that you will dine in style each meal.
We think its worth noting:
• It feels wonderfully remote and calming, though it may leave you longing for a little something extra.
  • There are not any real high energy excursions, although the range is good.
What they say about this accommodation: For me, the gem of the hotel is the ‘Wiliche’, the wooden boat. Whilst out on her, we pulled up alongside a small, local fishing boat to see what they were catching. We were offered some of their catch – local mussels and clams. Later in the afternoon the captain cooked these up with white wine, garlic and onions – delicious and so fresh.

Name: Refugio Chileno
Description: Refugio Chileno is the closest refugio to the base of the Towers, located approximately an hour and a half's hike away in the Ascencio Valley. This is a compact refugio, sleeping just 32 people in four dormitories, plus a campsite with permanent tents set on raised platforms amid the trees. There are shared bathrooms, a restaurant and a shop. Chileno is the perfect place to stay for those wanting to catch the sunrise over the Towers – which also means that it's one of the refugios that tends to book up farthest in advance.

Name: Refugio Cochamo
Description: This beautifully set hostal run by climbing experts Daniel and Silvina is the perfect base if you're looking for climbing expertise, a fun atmosphere and don't mind shared accommodation. They also serve up delicious pizzas!

Name: Refugio Cuernos
Description: Set at the heart of the W Trek near the entrance to French Valley, this refugio has wonderful views of the Cuernos and Nordenskjold Lake. Los Cuernos is a cosy 36 bed refugio divided into four dormitories, with a restaurant, shop, wood heating and shared bathrooms. Its location at the midpoint of the trail means that it's always busy with hikers walking in both directions. For those preferring a little more solitude, there are eight private twin cabins tucked into the trees. These have shared bathrooms and a hot tub, exclusively used by cabin guests. Refugio Los Cuernos is open all year.

Name: Refugio Dickson
Description: Hidden deep on the farthest point of the O Circuit, this is the most basic refugio in Torres del Paine, but also the one with some of the best views. It looks out from the shadow of forest slopes and snow-capped mountains across calm waters of Lake Dickson. There are just 27 bunk beds at Refugio Dickson, a bathroom block and an inviting chalet-style main hut that serves as a dining room, bar and communal area. The main site is surrounded by trees and has plenty of space for tents.

Name: Refugio Grey
Description: Refugio Grey is located at the western end of the W Trek, nestled among the trees on the shores of Lake Grey, and a short walk from the Glacier Grey lookout point. It is a modern refugio, sleeping up to 60 hikers in dormitory rooms of eight beds each. The accommodation is simple, but the communal areas, from the terraces with views to the lounges with sofas, do a great job in providing a warm and friendly sanctuary to relax in after a day of hiking. Refugio Grey is open all year.

Name: Refugio Paine Grande
Description: Refugio Paine Grande sits next to the catamaran dock on the northern shore of Lake Pehoé, one of the key points for either starting or finishing the W Trek. This is Torres del Paine’s largest (and arguably most comfortable) refugio, sleeping up to 100 hikers in dormitories of four or six people. All rooms have views of the Cuernos. There is a mini-market, bar and a large canteen-style restaurant. Paine Grande always feels bustling, thanks to the day hikers dropping in on their way to Lake Grey and the French Valley, plus campers at its large campsite. The refugio is open all year.

Name: Refugio Torre Central
Description: Torre Central is a large refugio situated near to the trailhead of the Base of the Towers trek. It’s a popular starting place for those hiking the W Trek from east to west, so it tends to book out very quickly in high season. This refugio sleeps 60 hikers in ten mixed dormitory rooms. It features a large and friendly communal area, male and female showers, a dining room, a bar and a shop. Central heating makes it a cosy overnight stop. There’s a large campsite among the bushes a short distance from the refugio. As it’s at the eastern end of the trek, access to the refugio is via the Laguna Amarga entrance to the national park.

Name: Remota Lodge
Description: The Remota is a luxury sanctuary just outside of town, with views across the Fjord of Last Hope. Perhaps not as remote as the name suggests, it's a fantastic choice for those who want to relax and enjoy amazing food at the end of a long trek. The building itself is fascinating and stylishly - if sometimes rather quirkily - designed. There's a spa, too.
What we like about this hotel:
• Despite being close to town, every room immerses you in Patagonia with vast windows framing the fjord.
  • Flawless design blends tradition and nature—wooden estancia-inspired architecture, a grass roof, and eco-friendly heating and lighting.
  • A standout selection of excursions, including hidden gems far from the crowds.
  • The à la carte menu delivers gourmet regional flavours—fresh, delicate, and packed with local ingredients. The desserts are delicious!
  • Unwind in the infinity pool and spa with huge windows to watch the landscape shift hues with the rising and setting sun.
We think its worth noting:
• The food can be repetitive if staying for more than a few nights.
  • Sometimes there is a long time to wait for meals and between courses (very tight for lunch).
  • National Geographic and other groups can take up most of the hotel on certain dates.
  • Remota Lodge is located on the outskirts of Puerto Natales and it takes over 2 hours to get to Torres del Paine in each direction. They run some fantastic alternative excursions that involve less travel time and more off the beaten trak Patagonia so that you can enjoy both the main highlights and some unique experiences.
What they say about this accommodation: There is an incredible serenity about this hotel with its bright, open spaces and beautiful traditional art throughout. The food was some of the best I've tried in the region - such creative dishes and delicate flavours.

Name: Rincón Chico
Description: The top destination in the Valdés area for spending time among elephant seals. The property is located in the south of the peninsula, and has it's own private beach and walking trails taking you within metres of the elephant seals. The accommodation is cosy and comfortable, with views over the steppe.

Name: Río Hermoso Hotel
Description: With only seven rooms and set in a secluded natural park bordering it's own creek, this beautiful wood and stone boutique mountain house provides the perfect base for exploring the surrounding area. The service is bespoke and your personalised itinerary can include hiking, kayaking, horse riding, fishing, biking, photography safaris and even skiing in the winter.

Name: Rio Palena Lodge
Description: Nestled in a secluded Andean valley beside the Río Palena in northern Aysen, this luxury lodge offers an ideal retreat for adventurers. Guests can indulge in gourmet breakfasts prepared by a private chef each morning and a morning of outdoor activities followed by a riverside lunch. Afterwards, unwind in the wood-fired hot tubs or sauna, taking in the serene surroundings. Explore untouched landscapes and be among the first to ski the snow-capped peaks of Patagonia's rugged terrain. For fishing enthusiasts, the lodge provides a gateway to a variety of fly fishing experiences, renowned for its abundant wild trout species including large brown and rainbow trout.
What we like about this hotel:
• This is the ultimate Patagonian adventure retreat—in a gorgeous, otherworldly location.
  • A private chef prepares creative breakfasts each morning and in the afternoon, savoury lunches will be served by your guide riverside.
  • Take your time soaking in the wood-fired hot tubs or sitting in the invigorating sauna.
  • Be among the first to get off the beaten track and ski the snow-capped peaks in this area of Chilean Patagonia.
  • Excellent fly fishing in a location famous for large, wild, brown and rainbow trout.
We think its worth noting:
• The remoteness and price point are not for everyone, but certainly for those looking for a unique slice of luxury.
  • There is the option for a 'full-lodge buyout' based on a party of up to 16 people.
What they say about this accommodation: The remoteness of Río Palena Lodge and the way it's operated makes it feel very different from a hotel. In fact, the area is so remote that when the guides started designing the excursions they had to name the peaks and glaciers!

Name: San Telmo Luxury Suites
Description: The only real high end choice in San Telmo. The hotel houses some stunning antiques and well thought out lounges and patios. The rooms are all on split levels offering a suites feel. The hotel has historic bars and cafes just around the corner so combines luxury and excellent service with the bohemian quirkiness of San Telmo.

Name: Santa Rita Vineyard
Description: Located to the south-east of Santiago, just 45 minutes from the international airport is the vineryard/winery where the Carmenere grape was 'rediscovered' in 1993. With a beautiful walled 40-hectare park, designed by leading French landscape gardener Guillaume Renner, Casa Real hotel is unique in Chile. There are just sixteen rooms, tastefully decorated with late-19th-century furniture, heirloom paintings and tapestries. Service and food are of excellent quality and reminiscent of an 'old-school' 5-star European hotel.

Name: Santiago Airport Holiday Inn
Description: The perfect place for any late-night or early-morning flights, the Holiday Inn can be found right outside Santiago's international airport. Whilst not as charming or unique as other options, the ease and practicality of walking off of a long-haul flight and into your hotel room late at night is certainly worth considering.

Name: Schilling
Description: This is a friendly B&B with simple rooms. The dining and communal areas have a warm ambience and are ideal for travellers to sit, relax and meet others. It is located two blocks from the main avenue on a fairly quiet residential street and very close to the supermarket.

Name: Senderos
Description: The staff are highly knowledgable and super friendly making the Senderos our favourite boutique hotel in El Chaltén. The rooms are on the cosy side but clever storage areas and neat bathrooms make this a great little haven for hiking. On a clear day you'll be able to see the classic mountain line from your room and you are just a stone's throw from the bus station. Our customers rave about the breakfast buffet with mounds of cake, fruit, cereals and more.

Name: Serrano Camp
Description: Serrano Camp is located at Pueblo Serrano outside the boundaries of Torres del Paine National Park, with tremendous views of the Paine massif. The camp has a series of deluxe bell tents linked by wooden walkways. A large communal dome tent is available for socialising and dining, with a four-course set dinners served every night. Each tent is designed for maximum cosiness, with electric heated blankets and private bathrooms. The camp was designed to create as low an environmental impact as possible, including a zero waste food policy, and was built using plastic-wood made from 20 tons of plastic waste produced in the region. Serrano Camp: Essential information: Located south of Torres del Paine National Park near the Serrano River with views of the Paine massif - A great base for the W Trek for those not wanting to stay in a refugio - Wildlife watching and horse-riding excursions available - Riverside location is the perfect starting location for kayak trips into the park - Friendly, communal atmosphere for hikers
Meals Available: Breakfast, Lunch, Box Lunch, Dinner, Snacks
What we like about this hotel:
• It's situated in a stunning spot—away from the crowds—an ideal base camp for the W Trek and other Torres del Paine excursions.
  • Deluxe tents are comfortable with thick mattress beds, duvets, pillows and heated blankets!
  • You won't go hungry with a tasty, well-earned 4-course gourmet dinner and full buffet breakfast to set you up for a day's hiking.
  • There's a growing focus on sustainability with the menu, camp design and a number of zero-waste initiatives.
  • The heated bathrooms make it really unique for a glamping experience.
We think its worth noting:
• Being a new creation the camp may feel exposed and cold due to a lack of trees and windbreaks.
  • The noise produced by the electric generator may disturb some guests' sleep.
  • There is very little lighting outside so you do need a head torch at night to move around (an authentic glamping experience!)
What they say about this accommodation: The camp boasts a splendid view of the Paine Massif; I loved waking up in the morning and sipping a coffee with THAT view in front of me.

Name: Simple Patagonia
Description: Just over three miles from Puerto Natales and right next to The Singular, Simple Patagonia is a quiet, minimalist hotel with sweeping views over the Última Esperanza Sound. It has just 10 rooms, built from native lenga wood and glass, so the views take centre stage whether you're in bed or at the breakfast table. The design is pared back, beautifully considered, and the atmosphere is calm and welcoming. It's run by a local family who are usually around to help or offer lifts to the airport. You’ll need a taxi to get into town, but the peace and space more than make up for it.

Name: Sofitel Buenos Aires Recoleta
Description: A wonderful 5* option in the heart of the city combining the best of Argentine and European culture in its cuisine and decor. Start the day with elegant blends of tea and coffee in the french artisan pastry, and choose from a range of fine Argentine wines in the brick bar by evening. Relaxation opportunities are particularly plentiful with a gym, indoor swimming pool, sauna and massage room. This is a great choice for those looking for luxury and comfort either for their one night stop over or during a multiple day stay in the city.

Name: Terra Luna Lodge
Description: There are a variety of rooms at Terra Luna. Enquire for more details.
What we like about this hotel:
• Owner Philippe has designed each lodge individually, resulting in an eclectic mix of accommodation including a boat, treehouses, small cabins and a whole family house.
  • Right on the lake, you can happily while away an afternoon swimming with a view of San Valentin across the lake. 
  • Despite being a remote lodge, some of the region's best-kept secrets, including the marble caves, are just a drive away
We think its worth noting: • On our visits we have found the service and food to be a bit hit and miss which is why we suggest people book the neighbouring hotel at Mirador de Guadal.

Name: Terrantai
Description: Centrally located and just a stone's throw from the main street in San Pedro, Terrantai is a really impressive boutique hotel focused on adventure, connection and culture. Built in 1996 the architecture is a fabulous mix of adobe, pebbles and wood and they even have a beautiful little courtyard pool. There is no restaurant here, but there is wine tasting every evening from 7-9pm which provides an excellent opportunity to get to know your fellow guests.

Name: Territorio
Description: The most luxurious option in Puerto Madryn - a small hotel of 36 rooms, decorated in simple Patagonian style, with lovely views over the Golfo Nuevo. Cosy fireplaces, big windows and beautiful views make for a lovely base from which to explore the area. If you're feeling lazy you can simply watch the whales cruise by from your bedroom window. The hotel is located on the edge of town, so it's a 20-minute walk or short taxi ride to the bars, restaurants and local tour operators, but arguably worth it for the views and comfort of the property.

Name: The Ritz-Carlton
Description: Situated just over a kilometre from Costanera Center in Santiago, The Ritz-Carlton offers 5-star accommodations with city views. Guests can enjoy amenities such as an indoor pool, free bikes, and a restaurant. Rooms feature air conditioning, a flat-screen TV, and a private bathroom with free toiletries. A buffet or American breakfast is available daily. The hotel also offers car hire, a business centre, and tour desk services. Santiago International Airport is 23km away, with an airport shuttle service available for a fee.

Name: The Singular Patagonia
Description: A former cold-storage facility with its own museum, The Singular wins over many on its architectural design alone - in 1996 the Chilean government declared it a 'National Historic Landmark'. At its heart sits a grand and popular restaurant, there's a waterfront spa, and spacious rooms offer impressive views of the Fjord of Last Hope. A great place to recuperate on the way to or from Torres del Paine National Park.
What we like about this hotel:
• You step back in time when walking through the doors of what was originally a cold storage plant, built in 1915, but transformed inside to be modern while maintaining many of the original features.
  • Despite the building's humble beginnings, your experience is one of total luxury in beautiful rooms with huge windows that overlook the water.
  • Taste the finest cuisine of the region at their excellent restaurant which also has sweeping views of the mountains and fjords.
  • Enjoy privately run kayak trips and boat excursions to visit nearby glaciers since the hotel has its own boat and kayaks.
  • The spa is not to be missed - chill in the pool, warm your limbs in the sauna or unwind with one (or more!) of the varied treatments on offer.
We think its worth noting: • The hotel's location, while offering calmness and scenic beauty, does have an 'out of town' feeling.
What they say about this accommodation: The Singular's excursions allow you to get off the beaten track and away from the crowds by revealing some of the hidden gems outside of Torres del Paine while still giving you the option to explore within the national park. Definitely make use of the sauna when you're back at the hotel!

Name: The Singular Santiago
Description: A boutique hotel, with 63 rooms. It's very well located in the city centre on the lovely streets of the Lastarria neighbourhood. With a rooftop terrace and outdoor pool, you can enjoy beautiful views over the city before returning to your spacious room. If you're looking for a luxurious base for a night or two in Santiago, this is a great option. We love the personalised service and the relaxed, yet elegant feel at one of Santiago’s most attractive and unique hotels.

Name: Tierra Atacama
Description: Tierra Atacama's philosophy is to be an 'adventure spa' - somewhere that allows you to explore the breath-taking desert landscape as actively as you please, and return each evening to a peaceful and relaxing retreat. The views from this lodge are the best, by far, in San Pedro, overlooking the oasis garden to volcanic peaks. They also have the top spa and pool facilities in the town. The 'quincho' on Saturday evenings is not to be missed.
Meals Available: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner, Snacks, Box Lunch
What we like about this hotel:
• The best views, by far, of any hotel in San Pedro with a landscape of volcano peaks, including Licancabor.
  • The best spa and pool in the area. There’s a cold water outside pool next to a hot water bath in which to warm up whilst you enjoy the beautiful oasis garden of natural native plants.
  • A broad range of half and full-day excursions are offered, with no minimum group sizes. Private vehicle use and excursions are included for guests staying in the suites.
  • The quincho every Saturday evening where tables are set around a fire pit with traditional Chilean musicians playing and an incredible BBQ.
  • After a couple of days filled with activities, you may feel like simply sitting down to relax by the pool and there is quite simply no better place to do it.
We think its worth noting: • The astronomy tour is not up there with a few rival hotels.
What they say about this accommodation: I love the fact that during the morning sunrise and evening sunset you get uninterrupted views of the most magical light playing over the panorama of volcanic peaks - a unique view from Tierra Patagonia.

Name: Tierra de Leyendas
Description: Perched above the Beagle Channel, Tierra de Leyendas is a cosy 7-room lodge steeped in local lore. Created by Sebastián, a passionate local, the hotel weaves the stories of Tierra del Fuego into every detail. Expect homemade breakfasts, a warm welcome, and personal touches throughout. With garden views, a greenhouse, and an outdoor jacuzzi overlooking the water, it’s a place to slow down and soak in the magic of the world’s southernmost city.

Name: Tierra Patagonia
Description: Tierra is one of the most striking buildings in Patagonia, and sits on a bluff above the shores of Lake Sarmiento Constructed of native lenga wood with a living roof, its airy spaces blend seamlessly into the landscape. The 40 rooms of this eco-luxe hotel all offer world-beating views of the Paine massif. There are a number of large suites, as well as interconnected superior rooms that can be joined to make family apartments. Tierra has a superb spa offering a range of treatments, as well as an indoor pool with the same tremendous views to Torres del Paine. After a day's excursions, guests can relax at the bar or dine at the hotel's excellent restaurant. Tierra Patagonia: Essential information: Located on the shores of Lake Sarmiento, with every room designed to offer truly extraordinary views - Wide variety of excursions in Torres del Paine, including the use of a private vehicle - Superb spa facilities and pool offer ultimate relaxation - Some of the best food and wine in the region - Social communal areas make it great for family and friends
Meals Available: Breakfast, Lunch, Box Lunch, Dinner, Snacks
What we like about this hotel:
• Tierra Patagonia is architecturally stunning: from the outside the building blends seamlessly into the landscape, from the inside it offers a light, airy and tranquil space.
  • Expansive panoramic views—from so many angles—with a wow factor. 
  • A broad range of excursions are offered/included, with no minimum group sizes. Private vehicle use and excursions are included for guests staying in the suites.
  • They have wonderful communal spaces including a pool & spa.
  • 5* service - staff are always on hand with personalised assistance. 
  • The informal atmosphere and communal areas make it a great place to socialise, but there are also plenty of quiet corners to relax.
We think its worth noting:
• Tierra is located just outside of the park entrance.
  • Half days are designed to come back to the hotel for lunch which means that you end up doing the same drive twice.
What they say about this accommodation: Of all of the luxury lodges in Torres del Paine, Tierra is my favourite. At the end of a day's exploring you still have those incredible views of Lago Sarmiento, the vast steppe, and the Paine Massif to enjoy over dinner, a glass of wine at the bar, or from your enormous bath tub.

Name: Vendaval
Description: This small and cozy accommodation nestled in the centre of Puerto Natales is just a short hop from the town square, the coastal walk and lots of great restaurants in the town. The 23 comfortable rooms, each equipped with a private bathroom, are great value for money. Up top, the hotel has a terrace and a chill-out lounge area with fantastic views of the city, mountains and water, making it the perfect spot to enjoy before or after your time in Torres del Paine.

Name: Vira Vira
Description:
Ideally appointed accommodation, overlooking either the estate surrounds or the Liucura River, includes six cosy suites, 12 split-level villas with a separate living room, and a five-bedroom, sole-use Hacienda for up to 10 guests.

Ensuite bathrooms include a separate bath and walk-in shower. Floor-to-ceiling windows fill the spacious wooden interiors with natural light.

Each guest unit is individually decorated with a selection of curated objects and richly-textured rugs, wall hangings and fabric.
What we like about this hotel:
• It’s the one true 5* all-inclusive option in & around Pucon.
  • The tranquil setting allows immediate access to the 'great outdoors' with adventurous activities for all abilities and inclinations.
  • The hotel itself is charming and built of native Lenga tree, a warm, sandy wood with woollen throws and private terraces.
  • As a Relais & Chateaux, you can expect excellent cuisine with an original, tasty and varied menu (breakfast, lunch and dinner!) with modern twists on local Chilean food traditions.
  • The water feature out front is a lovely spot to sit—as birds come & go—and you can enjoy a glass of wine, read a book or just take it all in...
We think its worth noting:
• It has a pretty remote feel, with gates to enter, and you'd have no idea that a town is nearby.
  • You cannot see the Villarrica volcano from the hotel.
  • There is no swimming pool.
What they say about this accommodation: Waking up to the river right outside my window was something special and I loved the comfort of the cosy wooden interiors. After a day of exploring, sinking into one of the outdoor hot tubs by the water felt like proper luxury. And the food? Almost everything came straight from their own greenhouse and cheese factory—fresh, local, and absolutely delicious.

Name: Weskar Lodge
Description: The Weskar Lodge enjoys a privileged location 3km out of town right by Last Hope Sound. The natural materials used in its construction give a warm, homely feel, with both relaxation and comfort of paramount importance. The accommodation features 21 comfortable rooms with spectacular views, whilst the in-house restaurant serves up sumptuous Patagonian dishes with regional beers and national wines. You’ll feel right at home at the Weskar.

Name: Wyndham Puerto Varas Pettra
Description: This centrally-located hotel has large, comfortable rooms, some with private balconies and all with views of Lake Llanquihue and the mountains beyond. The views from the superior rooms are particularly good. There are a total of 90 rooms, plus a highly-regarded restaurant, a spa, sauna and gym.

Name: Xelena
Description: This 4-star hotel with unparalleled views over the lake make it standout from the other Calafate accommodations with town just a 15-minute walk along the stunning coastline. If you’re looking to relax with spa treatment and wallow in the indoor/outdoor swimming pool whilst recovering from exploring the Andean mountains and glaciers nearby, then look no further.

Name: Yegua Loca
Description: Our favourite location in the city. A quirky 1920s heritage house in the foothills of Cerro de la Cruz with lovely views over the Magellan Strait. Yegua Loca is furnished with authentic vintage furniture and decorations, refurbished by hand by the hotel's friendly owners and each room is themed on a traditional Patagonian trade. It's only a few minutes walk from the main street and the waterfront and is next to the walkway to Mirador de la Cruz where you can take in panoramic views.
